A2O MAY, a new five-member girl group launched by A2O Entertainment, then took to the stage to perform their debut hit ‚ÄúUnder My Skin‚Äù (a remake of TVXQ!‚Äôs ‚ÄúMirotic‚Äù and Sarah Connor‚Äôs ‚ÄúUnder My Skin‚Äù) and their high-octane new single ‚ÄúBOSS.‚Äù
A2O MAY performing at Prime Video's LEE SOO MAN: THE KING OF K-POP Premiere held at NeueHouse ... More Hollywood in Hollywood, CA on Monday, ‚ÄãMay 12, 2025.Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA
Despite debuting only five months ago, A2O MAY has already set new records, becoming the first girl group from China to perform at a major American music festival (they recently played iHeartRadio‚Äôs Wango Tango) and the first Chinese idol girl group to break into the U.S. Top 40 Radio chart with ‚ÄúUnder My Skin."HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA - MAY 12: (L-R) Kat, Chenyu, Shijie, Quchang and Miche of A2O MAY attend the ... More premiere of Prime Video's "Lee Soo Man: The King of K-Pop" at NeueHouse Hollywood on May 12, 2025 in Hollywood, California.Frazer Harrison/Getty Images
Other young rookie acts from A2O Entertainment also showcased their talent on stage, stunning the audience with their explosive dance moves and an easy swagger well beyond their years.(L-R) A2O Entertainment Rookies - Tai, Hanze Jiayi, Ayden, Maxitong, Baowei and Xili at the Prime ... More Video's LEE SOO MAN: THE KING OF K-POP Premiere held at NeueHouse Hollywood in Hollywood, CA on Monday, ‚ÄãMay 12, 2025. (Photo By Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA)Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA
The night wrapped up with a lively rooftop afterparty, complete with an open bar, photo opps and a DJ set by Hyoyeon.(L-R) Hyoyeon of Girls' Generation and Lee Soo Man djing at Prime Video's LEE SOO MAN: THE KING OF ... More K-POP Premiere After Party held at NeueHouse Hollywood in Hollywood, CA on Monday, ‚ÄãMay 12, 2025.Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USAPrime Video's LEE SOO MAN: THE KING OF K-POP Premiere After Party held at NeueHouse Hollywood in ... More Hollywood, CA on Monday, ‚ÄãMay 12, 2025. (Photo By Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA)Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USAPrime Video's LEE SOO MAN: THE KING OF K-POP Premiere After Party held at NeueHouse Hollywood in ... More Hollywood, CA on Monday, ‚ÄãMay 12, 2025. (Photo By Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA)Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USAGuests at Prime Video's LEE SOO MAN: THE KING OF K-POP Premiere held at NeueHouse Hollywood in ... More Hollywood, CA on Monday, ‚ÄãMay 12, 2025. (Photo By Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA)Sthanlee B. Mirador/Sipa USA
Lee Soo Man: King of K-Pop delves into Lee‚Äôs remarkable career and profound impact on the Korean entertainment industry, from his beginnings as a popular singer-songwriter in Korea to his rise as the visionary founder and chief producer of SM Entertainment, one of the largest K-pop agencies in the world. The documentary also addresses the controversies that led to his ouster from SM Entertainment and traces his subsequent remarkable comeback as the founder and lead producer of A2O Entertainment.HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA - MAY 12: Lee Soo Man attends the premiere of Prime Video's "Lee Soo Man: The ... More King of K-Pop" at NeueHouse Hollywood on May 12, 2025 in Hollywood, California. (Photo by Amy Sussman/GA/The Hollywood Reporter via Getty Images)The Hollywood Reporter via Getty
During his time at SM Entertainment, Lee created and refined the K-pop idol system that is responsible for shaping K-pop as we know it today. Under Lee‚Äôs guidance, many of SM Entertainment‚Äôs earlier artists like H.O.T. (widely considered to be the first K-pop idol group), TVXQ!, BoA and Super Junior popularized K-pop in overseas markets and laid the foundations for K-pop to grow into a global phenomenon. As the documentary notes, beginning with its boy band EXO, SM Entertainment also introduced ‚Äúconcepts‚Äù (an overarching theme for an artist or one of their albums) and ‚Äúuniverses‚Äù (fictional worlds built around a particular K-pop group that often involve elaborate storylines) into K-pop storytelling that became widely adopted across the K-pop industry over the years.
Lee Soo Man: King of K-Pop is available to stream on Amazon Prime Video.ForbesOne Hundred Label, K-Pop Agency Behind THE BOYZ, Partners With Hello82By Regina Kim

title: Little Golden Book‚Äôs First K-Pop Bio Takes BTS From Dreams To Stardom
description: The author of 'BTS: A Little Golden Book Biography' wanted to share their inspiring story with a younger audience.
full_text:
BTS is the first k-pop group to get its own Little Golden Books biography.Penguin Random House
BTS are the world‚Äôs biggest k-pop band and they also have one of the world‚Äôs most loyal fandoms, the many millions of global fans called Army. During the course of their very successful career BTS have earned many accolades‚Äîincluding Billboard Awards, American Music Awards, People‚Äôs Choice Awards, Golden Disc Awards and several Grammy nominations‚Äîbut 2025 is the first time the band will grace the cover of a Little Golden Book. Younger readers will be able to enjoy a bio of the k-pop band when BTS: A Little Golden Book Biography is released in the fall.


It‚Äôs fitting that the bio was written by Jan Ann, a children‚Äôs book writer and longtime BTS fan. Ann was introduced to the band by her daughter, who has been a BTS fan since 2013.

‚ÄúIt was 2018, we were watching the Billboard Music Awards where they won the top social artists and performed ‚ÄòFake Love‚Äô for the first time,‚Äù said Ann. ‚ÄúAfter that I thought, well, they‚Äôre really amazing. So I started watching all their music videos and their performances and dance practices and live streams. They have so much content. And then we saw them in concert in 2019 during the world tour, the Love Yourself: Speak Yourself tour.‚Äù

Something about the performers‚Äô personalities and the way they interacted with each other really resonated with Ann. There‚Äôs a lot she likes about k-pop in general, but BTS is now her favorite band and holds a special place in her heart.


‚ÄúI love that k-pop is just such a visual medium,‚Äù said Ann. ‚ÄúWell thought out concepts for everything. With BTS, there‚Äôs just a unique style and an aesthetic for every song that they have. And sometimes they‚Äôll even have more than one concept for a song. It‚Äôs so fun to see what they‚Äôll come up with next. I love their interactions with each other, their individual personalities, their sense of humor and all their content, such as Run BTS and In The Soop. And that's not even counting their amazing performances. The choreography that they have is so powerful.‚Äù(L-R) Jimin, Jungkook, RM, J-Hope, V, Jin, and SUGA of the K-pop band BTS on a past visit to the ... More "Today" Show in New York City. (Photo by Cindy Ord/WireImage)WireImage
MORE FOR YOU

Ann liked the band so much she wanted to share their story and considered ways to write about them for younger readers. One option was the Golden Books imprint, under Penguin Random House, which publishes biographies about interesting people from diverse backgrounds. Other Golden Book bios include Taylor Swift, Dolly Parton, Rihanna, the Beatles, Caitlin Clark, Simone Biles, Billy Porter, Michelle Yeoh, Carol Burnett, Jane Goodall, Jimmy Carter, Oprah Winfrey, Audrey Hepburn, Pope Francis, Chappell Roan and the Kelce Brothers. While the imprint published biographies in the past, the series really took off in 202o with a book about Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. The 2025 bio roster also includes books on Michael J. Fox, Serena Williams, Cher, and Rosa Parks.
‚ÄúWhen I saw the biographies," she said. ‚ÄúI thought that would probably be perfect.‚Äù
Her biography follows the journey taken by BTS members RM, Jin, Suga, J-Hope, Jimin, V and Jungkook from their early days charting how they became one of the world‚Äôs biggest music groups, noting the success of songs like ‚ÄúDynamite,‚Äù and mentioning career highlights, such as the time the band spoke at the UN about the power of young people to change the world. It was challenging to decide which parts of the band‚Äôs event-filled musical journey to fit in such a slim volume.

‚ÄúWith all they have achieved, there‚Äôs so much content,‚Äù said Ann. "So the book focuses on their early years, how they got their start together in South Korea and a few of the key points in their journey toward becoming the biggest music group in the world. It was hard to fit it all in, especially with the bios in the beginning with seven members. Each person gets a page. Then some of the highlights were speaking at the UN and performances such as when they first went to the AMAs in 2017 and performed ‚ÄúDNA‚Äù and then how that did so well on YouTube, how many views it had. Just a few key points of so many to choose from."


Already pre-orders for the BTS bio have bumped the title to the top of the yet-to-be-published Golden Book biographies list. Could it be parents who fondly remember buying Golden Books as a child that are ordering this title? That‚Äôs one possibility, said Ann.
‚ÄúI think there is a nostalgia factor since so many adults grew up reading the Little Golden Books," said Ann. ‚ÄúMany people have purchased them for themselves as a collector‚Äôs item. Also since the age range of Army is so great ‚Äîfrom 2 to 102‚Äîthere are Army parents, grandparents, teachers, caregivers, who may want to introduce BTS to the children in their lives through a simple storyline like a Little Golden Book. And with BTS‚Äô journey being so inspirational, I think it's a positive story to share with others.‚Äù
When Ann first became a fan, BTS was just becoming popular in the U.S. As a band and as solo performers, BTS are even more successful now, but, according to Ann, they have not let success change them.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing how humble and generous they remain, as successful as they are," she said. ‚ÄúAnd I'm so excited for their comeback.‚Äù
By June all seven BTS members will have completed the mandatory military service required of able-bodied South Korean males. Although individual members have recently released music, the band has not performed together for a few years.
The BTS biography is the series‚Äô first k-pop bio, but it won‚Äôt be the last. A biography of k-pop performers Blackpink is planned for December.
‚ÄúI think BTS are very inspiring role models for kids,‚Äù said Ann. ‚ÄúThey worked hard to pursue their dreams and never gave up and have always remained incredibly humble and generous. And those are all qualities that would be inspiring to kids.‚Äù
BTS: A Little Golden Book Biography was illustrated by Hyesung Park, an art director at Pixar Animation Studios.  The Golden Book bio hits the shelves on Sept. 2.

title: Los 7 estrenos imprescindibles de Netflix en junio de 2025. Del esperad√≠simo final de 'El juego del calamar' a la versi√≥n espa√±ola de un reality de √©xito mundial
description: En breve toca dejar atr√°s mayo y centrarnos en el mes que viene. Por ello, en Espinof vamos a hacer nuestro ya tradicional repaso a 7 estrenos imprescindibles de Netflix durante junio de 2025. Entre los t√≠tulos elegidos sobresale con luz propia el esperad√≠sim‚Ä¶
full_text:
En breve toca dejar atr√°s mayo y centrarnos en el mes que viene. Por ello, en Espinof vamos a hacer nuestro ya tradicional repaso a 7 estrenos imprescindibles de Netflix durante junio de 2025. Entre los t√≠tulos elegidos sobresale con luz propia el esperad√≠simo final de 'El juego del calamar', pero hay propuestas para todos los gustos.
 

 
  
 
 
   
               
       'Ginny y Georgia', temporada 3
      
                    
       'FUBAR', temporada 2
      
                    
       'Jugando con fuego: Espa√±a'
      
                    
       'Aguas turbias'
      
                    
       'Las guerreras K-Pop'
      
                    
       'Olympo'
      
                    
       'El juego del calamar 3'
      
            
  
'Ginny y Georgia', temporada 3

 
   
   
      

Uno de los grandes √©xitos de Netflix regresa casi dos a√±os y medio despu√©s con una tercera entrega que promete indagar m√°s en la historia de la peculiar familia formada por Brianne Howley y Antonia Gentry. Recordemos que la anterior entrega concluy√≥ con un tremendo cliffhanger -el arresto de Georgia-, por lo que los nuevos episodios se presentan moviditos.

 
 
   
                         
       
  
 LAS 10 MEJORES SERIES DE LA D√âCADA (2010-2019)


Estreno en Netflix el 5 de junio de 2025

   
     
    
   
   
  
'FUBAR', temporada 2

 
   
   
      

Dos a√±os despu√©s vuelve la serie de acci√≥n protagonizada por Arnold Schwarzenegger. √âl fue lo mejor de la primera entrega y mucho me sorprender√≠a que eso vaya a cambiar en la segunda. Eso s√≠, ojo al fichaje de Carrie-Anne Moss, pues espero que tenga oportunidad para lucirse.
 
Estreno en Netflix en 12 de junio

'Jugando con fuego: Espa√±a'

 
   
   
      

Reconozco que no soy muy fan de este formato de Netflix -me vi y disfrut√© hasta cierto punto con la primera edici√≥n del original, pero luego acab√© saturado-, lo cual no quita que tenga un enorme √©xito y cuenta con versiones en varios pa√≠ses. Ahora le toca el turno a Espa√±a en una edici√≥n presentada por Alba Carrillo que promete dar mucho de lo que hablar.

Estreno en Netflix el 13 de junio

'Aguas turbias'

 
   
   
      

Holt McCallany y Melissa Benoist lideran esta serie dram√°tica basada en hechos reales que cuenta c√≥mo una familia recurre a todo tipo de m√©todos para mantener a flote su imperio pesquero. Detr√°s de ella tenemos a Kevin Williamson ('Dawson crece').

Estreno en Netflix el 18 de junio

'Las guerreras K-Pop'

 
   
   
      

Nueva pel√≠cula animada de Netflix que mezcla el cine de superh√©roes con el mundo del k-pop. Cuenta la historia de varias superestrellas de ese tipo de m√∫sica que utilizan sus incre√≠bles poderes secretos para proteger a sus fans cuando no est√°n tocando ante el p√∫blico.
 

Estreno en Netflix el 20 de junio

   
     
    
   
   
  
'Olympo'

 
   
   
      

Huele a intento de conseguir una nueva '√âlite', lo √∫nico que en esta ocasi√≥n situando la historia en un centro deportivo de alto rendimiento. Clara Galle es el rostro m√°s reconocible de una serie llamada a conectar con el p√∫blico adolescente y convertirse en el nuevo bombazo espa√±ol de Netflix.

Estreno en Netflix el 20 de junio

'El juego del calamar 3'

 
   
   
      

El gran final de la serie m√°s vista de la historia de Netflix. Nos quedan por delante solamente 6 episodios para descubrir c√≥mo se cierra la historia de Gi-hun, quien se encuentra en una posici√≥n especialmente delicada tras el fallido intento de rebeli√≥n que tuvo lugar al final de la segunda temporada.

Estreno en Netflix el 27 de junio

title: –§–∞–Ω–∞—Ç—ã K-pop —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–ª–∏ —Å–ø—Ä–æ—Å –Ω–∞ –ø–æ—Å—É—Ç–æ—á–Ω—É—é –∞—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—É —Ñ–ª–∞–≥–º–∞–Ω—Å–∫–∏—Ö —Å–º–∞—Ä—Ç—Ñ–æ–Ω–æ–≤ Samsung
Miles de 'pornoanuncios' en Facebook e Instagram conduc√≠an... a anuncios fraudulentos en Google. As√≠ era esta pr√°ctica tan rentable
description: "Nada mejor para hacernos ver que estamos ante un "ecosistema publicitario online saludable" que usar anuncios enga√±osos en una plataforma para dirigir el tr√°fico a anuncios enga√±osos en otra plataforma", afirma el experto en verificaci√≥n de datos y antiguo e‚Ä¶
full_text:
"Nada mejor para hacernos ver que estamos ante un "ecosistema publicitario online saludable" que usar anuncios enga√±osos en una plataforma para dirigir el tr√°fico a anuncios enga√±osos en otra plataforma", afirma el experto en verificaci√≥n de datos y antiguo empleado de Google Alexios Mantzarlis en su nueva publicaci√≥n.
 

Lo que Mantzarlis ha expuesto es una sofisticada campa√±a de publicidad enga√±osa que se ha aprovechado de las plataformas de Meta y Google para defraudar a los usuarios.


 
 
 'Sgroogled.com': cuando MICROSOFT lanzaba anuncios ANTI-GOOGLE

'Porno' como se√±uelo

Han detectado la presencia de m√°s de 3.500 anuncios de "pornbait" ‚Äîesto es, de publicidad que simula ofrecer contenido pornogr√°fico como gancho‚Äî en el ecosistema publicitario de Meta, particularmente en Facebook. Estos anuncios, con im√°genes 'sugerentes' (en ocasiones robadas de Internet), promet√≠an al usuario dirigirlo a v√≠deos 'XXX' y a 'shows en directo'...
  

...pero al hacer clic, los usuarios eran redirigidos a p√°ginas web que no conten√≠an el contenido prometido, sino que estaban saturadas de anuncios gestionados por Google, camuflados como resultados de b√∫squeda o portales informativos.

     
   
   
        (v√≠a Indicator)
   
   
Un ejemplo citado por Mantzarlis muestra una imagen de una mujer (en realidad, un icono del K-Pop) y el mensaje de "Pulsa para ver pel√≠cula sin censura. Date prisa antes de que la borren"; otro invita al usuario a "hacer clic en cualquier palabra relacionada con 'abogado de divorcios'" (arriba) para obtener acceso a un v√≠deo expl√≠cito.

     
   
   
        Los responsables de esta trama robaban anuncios de 'celebrities' para sus anuncios (v√≠a Indicator)
   
   
Por si no lo hab√≠as visto venir a estas alturas, todo resultaba ser una trampa dise√±ada para maximizar ingresos publicitarios manipulando al usuario para que visualice los anuncios program√°ticos de Google.
 

Un negocio tan fraudulento como rentable

Aunque Meta no revela m√©tricas completas sobre el alcance de estos anuncios, los datos p√∫blicos sobre campa√±as dirigidas a ciudadanos de la Uni√≥n Europea estiman que estos activos podr√≠an haber sido vistos entre 50.000 y 20 millones de veces. En algunos casos, tal como revela el an√°lisis de tr√°fico web de Similarweb, el 83% del tr√°fico mensual de una de las webs promocionadas proven√≠a directamente de Facebook.

   
     
    
   
   
  
El 'modus operandi' es muy simple: atraer al usuario con un contenido expl√≠cito ficticio, dirigirlo a una p√°gina con textos generados por inteligencia artificial como relleno, y bombardearlo con anuncios publicitarios automatizados. Y as√≠ los beneficios, tanto para los operadores del esquema como para las plataformas involucradas, se acumulan con cada impresi√≥n.

El rol de Meta y Google, en duda

Tras contactar Mantzarlis con ambas compa√±√≠as, Meta elimin√≥ todos los anuncios y p√°ginas relacionadas, alegando que violaban sus pol√≠ticas. Por su parte, Google procedi√≥ a desmonetizar algunos de los sitios involucrados.

Sin embargo, esta actuaci√≥n meramente reactiva, y no proactiva, pone en entredicho a ambas plataformas: aunque ganan miles de millones de d√≥lares a trav√©s de publicidad, al menos en este caso no han resultado ser eficaces para filtrar contenido fraudulento antes de que este alcance a millones de usuarios.
 

Imagen | Marcos Merino mediante IA

title: Corea del Norte y Corea del Sur libran una guerra invisible (y Kim va ganando)
description: Mientras los misiles est√°n en pausa, Corea del Norte y Corea del Sur libran un conflicto distinto: una guerra de informaci√≥n. USB, K-pop y series de Netflix contra represi√≥n, ejecuciones y tel√©fonos controlados. Y en esta batalla sin disparos, todo indica que‚Ä¶
full_text:
Aunque Corea del Norte y Corea del Sur firmaron un armisticio en 1953, nunca terminaron oficialmente la guerra. Hoy, el frente est√° en otro terreno: la informaci√≥n. No se disparan misiles, pero s√≠ canciones pop, USB con series extranjeras y transmisiones clandestinas. En las √∫ltimas semanas, Corea del Sur reactiv√≥ los altavoces propagand√≠sticos que apuntan al norte con m√∫sica y mensajes sobre libertad. Al otro lado, Corea del Norte responde con himnos militares a todo volumen. Es una especie de duelo sonoro, pero lo m√°s intenso ocurre en silencio, bajo tierra o en la oscuridad de la noche. Las armas: dramas coreanos, memoria USB y ondas de radio ¬© ƒ∞rem √áilingir ‚Äì Pexels Desde hace a√±os, activistas y desertores env√≠an USB con contenido prohibido: dramas de Netflix, canciones de BTS, tutoriales sobre democracia. Estos dispositivos cruzan la frontera en cajas de fruta o flotan por los r√≠os, burlando cercas y patrullas.

 Organizaciones como Unification Media Group crean cuidadosamente listas con dos tipos de contenidos: entretenimiento ‚Äúseguro‚Äù y material educativo altamente prohibido. Lo primero inspira curiosidad, lo segundo, peligro.

 Y funciona. Muchos desertores aseguran que estas series fueron su despertar. Ver libertad, riqueza y posibilidades en la pantalla los llev√≥ a cuestionar el sistema y, en algunos casos, a huir.

 ¬´Llor√© viendo una serie surcoreana. Me hizo so√±ar con otra vida¬ª, cont√≥ Kang Gyuri, una joven que escap√≥ del norte en barco en 2023. Kim contraataca: ejecuciones, censura y vigilancia total ¬© Thomas Evans ‚Äì Unsplash El r√©gimen de Kim Jong-un est√° al tanto del peligro que representa esta ‚Äúinvasi√≥n cultural‚Äù y ha respondido con dureza. Nuevas leyes ordenan penas de prisi√≥n e incluso la muerte para quienes vean contenido extranjero. J√≥venes son ejecutados por tener videos de K-pop en sus tel√©fonos.

 Adem√°s, ¬´escuadrones de represi√≥n juvenil¬ª recorren las calles. Castigan a quien use palabras con acento surcoreano, vista de forma ¬´occidental¬ª o hable de actores extranjeros. Los tel√©fonos norcoreanos incluso autocensuran palabras: si escribes ‚Äúoppa‚Äù (hermano mayor, en estilo K-drama), el sistema lo borra o reemplaza.

 Y el contrabando se ha vuelto m√°s dif√≠cil. Durante la pandemia, Corea del Norte reforz√≥ la frontera con cercas el√©ctricas y nuevas patrullas. Ahora, solo los m√°s valientes se atreven a cruzar informaci√≥n. Estados Unidos se retira‚Ä¶ y Corea del Norte avanza ¬© Micha Br√§ndli ‚Äì Unsplash La mayor√≠a de las operaciones para informar a los norcoreanos han sido financiadas por el gobierno de EE.UU. Sin embargo, con el regreso de Donald Trump al poder, se suspendieron fondos clave a medios como Voice of America y Radio Free Asia.

 La excusa: reducir ¬´gastos en propaganda radical¬ª. El resultado: Kim tiene menos enemigos en el campo informativo. Activistas advierten que, sin este apoyo, la guerra de la informaci√≥n se estanca. Y Corea del Sur no parece dispuesto a tomar la posta: el conflicto est√° demasiado politizado. El candidato presidencial favorito incluso prometi√≥ apagar los altavoces si gana las elecciones. Una esperanza persistente‚Ä¶ aunque silenciosa Pese a la represi√≥n, los cambios culturales est√°n sembrando algo. ¬´El gobierno no puede borrar lo que ya est√° en la mente de la gente¬ª, dicen los activistas. Aunque a√∫n no hay protestas masivas, hay algo nuevo: j√≥venes que piensan distinto, que sue√±an, que comparan. Y mientras los USB sigan flotando r√≠o abajo, la guerra silenciosa continuar√°. [Fuente: BBC en Espa√±ol]

title: Lisa Matches BTS In A Major Chart Feat
description: Lisa earns her second solo entry on Billboard‚Äôs Adult Contemporary chart with ‚ÄúPriceless,‚Äù her collaboration with Maroon 5,  tying BTS's record as she arrives.
full_text:
Lisa earns her second solo entry on Billboard‚Äôs Adult Contemporary chart with ‚ÄúPriceless,‚Äù her ... More collaboration with Maroon 5,  tying BTS's record as she arrives.   Thai singer and actress Lalisa Manoban known as Lisa attends the 97th Annual Academy Awards at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, California on March 2, 2025. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP) (Photo by ANGELA WEISS/AFP via Getty Images)AFP via Getty Images 
Last week, Lisa returned to a number of Billboard charts as a soloist alongside Maroon 5. The pop band recruited the Blackpink superstar to lend some star power to its new single, and the plan worked.


"Priceless" quickly became a hit across several pop radio formats. This frame, the tune debuts on yet another one of Billboard‚Äôs rosters dedicated to showcasing what pop cuts America is hearing on the airwaves. As it arrives, the singer and rapper matches one of the biggest names in the K-pop space in a very specific fashion.

Lisa‚Äôs New Radio Hit
"Priceless" opens at No. 29 on the Adult Contemporary chart this week. It earns Lisa her second career win as a soloist on the tally. She first debuted on her own with "Moonlit Floor (Kiss Me)," which arrived only a few weeks ago in March and spent 10 weeks on the list before disappearing.


Lisa Matches BTS‚Äôs Feat
Lisa is just the second K-pop act to appear on the Adult Contemporary chart more than once ‚Äî and she‚Äôs the first soloist to manage the feat. BTS became the first South Korean musical act to accrue a pair of wins, and then the first to snag three, several years ago. In 2021, the septet reached the ranking with "Dynamite" and "Butter," as well as "My Universe," the group‚Äôs collaboration with Coldplay.

 
While Lisa is originally from Thailand, she‚Äôs most closely associated with the South Korean music industry and with K-pop. Much of her solo output can be classified under different pop subgenres, but since she got her start as a member of Blackpink, she‚Äôs usually considered a K-pop musician as well.

MORE FOR YOU
‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù With Maroon 5 is on the Rise
As it debuts on the Adult Contemporary chart, "Priceless" rises on both the Pop Airplay and Adult Pop Airplay tallies, where it launched last frame. This time around, it jumps four spaces to No. 22 on the former tally and five spots to No. 12 on the latter list, coming in just below the top 10. There‚Äôs a good chance that, thanks to the popularity of the cut and Maroon 5‚Äôs impressive track record, the two may jump into the highest tier on the Adult Pop Airplay ranking in just a few days.

title: What Head in The Clouds 2025 meant to a 2nd generation K-pop fan
description: At Head in the Clouds 2025, headlining sets from K-pop trailblazers G-Dragon and 2NE1 were reminiscent, and a reminder, of their decades-long influence in music.
full_text:
Courtesy of Head in the Clouds
    
  







  











    



  






          
            Despite it being one of Los Angeles‚Äô hottest days of the year, around 36,000 people are piled at Head in the Cloud‚Äôs main stage for the final performance of the festival‚Äôs first day. It‚Äôs a little after 10 p.m. on Saturday when the star of the night, G-Dragon, is ushered onto the stage by a troupe of backup dancers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the GOAT, the living legend,‚Äù he boasts by way of introduction before easing into the explosive flow of his new track, ‚ÄúPower.‚Äù Tonight, the fashion maven is dressed in a lion-embroidered Gucci jacket, splotchy bleached jeans, and chunky loafers. By his second song, ‚ÄúHome Sweet Home‚Äù ‚Äî featuring his fellow Big Bang bandmates Taeyang and Daesung who aren‚Äôt physically present at the festival but appear on the jumbo screen during their respective verses ‚Äî he‚Äôll remove his Balenciaga frames and black fedora to display freshly dyed pink spikes.
          

            










          
            A looming titan of K-pop, G-Dragon hasn‚Äôt stepped on an U.S. stage since 2017, and this is his first-time ever headlining a U.S. music festival. The historical significance of this show isn‚Äôt lost on this crowd which seems to be in a state of constant eruption. His 11-track set is fine-tuned to maximize this moment, wheeling through 2010s fan-favorites like ‚ÄúOne of A Kind‚Äù and ‚ÄúCrayon‚Äù and tracks from his 2024 studio album √úbermensch. When he plays his 2017 hype hit ‚ÄúBullshit,‚Äù he remixes in segments of Kendrick Lamar‚Äôs ‚ÄúNot Like Us,‚Äù going as far to integrate the rapper‚Äôs iconic walk from the 2025 Super Bowl halftime show into his choreography. It feels like a statement on their mutual cultural standings, something that‚Äôs further underlined when he brings out surprise guest and former labelmate CL to perform 2009‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Leaders‚Äù: G-Dragon knows he‚Äôs an icon and has been an icon since his 2006 debut in the K-pop mega boy band, BIGBANG.
          



              





      




      






    



  
  
  







  

      Courtesy of Head in the Clouds
    
  






  
  







  

      Courtesy of Head in the Clouds
    
  





  











    



  






          
            Hours after the festival has wrapped I catch up with the industry-dubbed ‚ÄúKing of K-pop‚Äù at the artist compound backstage where he‚Äôs makeup-free and unwinding with a glass of white wine. ‚ÄúI missed this vibe, especially at an outdoor festival,‚Äù he tells me in English. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs different from any of my concerts. Here, I feel like I can just chill.‚Äù 
          










          
            A few nights from now, he‚Äôll be flying to Macau to continue his √úbermensch world tour. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sad because we had two songs left that we couldn‚Äôt play,‚Äù he says of tonight‚Äôs performance, noting that he ‚Äúfeels sorry‚Äù that he couldn‚Äôt perform more for his fans. Despite that, he says he feels more excited than ever to be back on stage. ‚Äú[For] now, it makes me want to keep doing this.‚Äù
          

            





      










    



  

  
  









  

      Courtesy of Head in the Clouds
    
  







  











    



  






          
            If you were to ask G-Dragon‚Äôs fanbase even two years ago, they wouldn‚Äôt have expressed any hope of seeing him perform live again as he was deep into a seven-year hiatus that he recently was reawakened from in 2024. Fans probably could‚Äôve said the same about Head in the Cloud‚Äôs other headliner 2NE1, who disbanded in 2016 and whose last U.S. performance was a surprise reunion at Coachella 2022 (also with HITC). Gravitas-filled, exhilarating showings was the theme of this year‚Äôs Head in the Clouds, 88rising‚Äôs annual music and arts festival that‚Äôs become an ‚ÄúAsian Coachella‚Äù of sorts in terms of scope and cultural impact. 
          

            










          
            Between energetic debuts ‚Äî like that of the soon-to-be-massive Indonesian pop group No Na ‚Äî and spots from emerging stars like Chinese-Canadian indie singer yung kai, Chinese-American singer Sunkis, and Thai rapper Milli, this year‚Äôs lineup showed off the rich and wide breadth of music being made by Asian, and Asian-descendant artists in music today. Korean powerhouses Dean and DPR Ian, who were among my most anticipated performers, allured crowds with heartstopping ballads and by taking their shirts off. But it was the fervent anticipation of G-Dragon and 2NE1‚Äôs appearances that defined the tone of the weekend. Decades after their debuts, their headlining performances marked a triumphant return to the forefront, and a resurgence of K-pop‚Äôs second generation.
          





      










    



  
  
  






    
      Seiji Oda at HITC 2025.
    

  
      ¬†

    
  






  
  






    
      Tabber at HITC 2025.
    

  
      ¬†

    
  





  





      






    



  
  
  






    
      yung kai at HITC 2025.
    

  
      ¬†

    
  






  
  






    
      MILLI at HITC 2025.
    

  
      ¬†

    
  





  











    



  



      








    
      DPR Ian at HITC 2025.
    

  
      ¬†

    
  







      

  










    



  






          
            Unlike other music genres, K-pop defines their artists by cultural eras. K-pop‚Äôs second generation, spanning roughly from 2003 to 2012, was the one that pushed the genre into mainstream popularity, kicking off what‚Äôs now known as the Hallyu wave. That era introduced innovation, musical experimentation, and an influx of idol groups ‚Äî among them BIGBANG and 2NE1, two forces that had such a colossal impact on the industry it wouldn‚Äôt be an understatement to say they created the blueprint of what we consider K-pop to be today. That HITC had two of K-pop‚Äôs most iconic forebears at one event felt like a reminder of their influence and record-breaking contributions. Like many of the 60,000 spectators who reportedly attended the festival, I showed up to see the artists who‚Äôd informed so much of my Korean pop culture knowledge, and my Korean heritage, as a pre-teen. And like many of the fans present, too, it was the first time I‚Äôd see either of them in the flesh.
          

            










          
            Two hours before 2NE1‚Äôs set on day two, I pushed my way to the front to get a close-up view of the girl group who were my entry points into that world. At 8:15 p.m., members CL, Sandara Park, and Minzy bursted into a 12-song frenzy down nostalgia lane. The group‚Äôs fourth member, Park Bom, withdrew from the festival citing personal circumstances. But even with her absence, the trio enthusiastically carried on. When Bom‚Äôs absence was felt ‚Äî her deep vocal range simply can‚Äôt be recreated ‚Äî the gaps were filled by the crowd singing along. (‚ÄúSing it for Bom,‚Äù CL directed at the start of their set.) 
          





      










    



  




      






    



  




      
            They kicked things off with their 2009 debut song ‚ÄúFire‚Äù before tackling their major hits in succession. Fans thrashed to ‚ÄúI Am the Best‚Äù and ‚ÄúClap Your Hands,‚Äù while ballads ‚ÄúUgly‚Äù and ‚ÄúLonely‚Äù were belted at the top of our lungs. I‚Äôd be lying if I said I didn‚Äôt shed a tear or two. As branded light sticks and fan merch waved high above in the final moments of 2NE1‚Äôs set, I realized that I‚Äôd just experienced a historic reunion of K-pop‚Äôs second generation icons that I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôll get to witness again.

title: Netflix‚Äôs ‚ÄòKPop Demon Hunters‚Äô Releases Their Trailer And Poster
description: Netflix's 'KPop Demon Hunters' release their trailer and official poster. The anticipated  animated musical film is set to premiere on June 20 on Netflix.
full_text:
KPOP Demon HuntersNetflix
Netflix‚Äôs KPop Demon Hunters have released their trailer, and it‚Äôs safe to say, it‚Äôs poppin‚Äô!

Imagine if your favorite K-pop stars moonlit as demon hunters. While they‚Äôre killing it on the stage, they‚Äôre actually killing demons between comebacks and touring. The three idols ‚Äì Rumi (Arden Cho), Mira (May Hong), and Zoey (Ji-young Yoo) ‚Äì from the group, Huntrix, use their secret identities as idols to protect their fans and the world from supernatural threats. The demons seem to have their own plans by utilizing that K-pop power and creating their demonic boy band, The Saja Boys‚Äì stealing hearts and souls.


The musical animated film, directed by Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans, sets the scene in Seoul, with Korean people at the center. In the trailer, several Korean ajummas (elderly ladies), fan girls and boys are seen in the crowd.

Kang told EW, ‚ÄúIt was really my desire to see Korean people on film in animation. So it actually started off as just a demon hunter project where I wanted to showcase Korean demons. Because demon hunting is usually a side job that‚Äôs done in secret, it was like, what is their day job?‚Äù

K-Pop Demon Hunters Official PosterNetflix
Produced by Sony Pictures Animation, the same people who brought the Spider-verse films, the animations shown throughout the trailer are wild. From the graphic fight scenes to the goofy faces to the hilarious reactions to a sexy boyband, KPop Demon Hunters may be exactly what K-pop fans and animation fans are looking for.
Play Puzzles & Games on Forbes

Not to mention, TWICE‚Äôs Jeongyeon, Jihyo, and Chaeyoung are part of the film‚Äôs soundtrack, with their version of ‚ÄúTakedown.‚Äù The trio told EW described the song as ‚Äúa high-energy track with a powerful beat,‚Äù that‚Äôs ‚Äúfilled with fierce determination and the will to tear down anything fake.‚Äù
How much more K-pop can this movie get?
Oh, but there‚Äôs more!

Teddy Park ‚Äì the brains behind BLACKPINK‚Äôs music ‚Äì helped develop the music for the film. He worked with 24, Danny Chung, IDO, Vince, KUSH, and DOMINSUK. K-pop songwriters and producers were also involved in the process, including EJAE, Jenna Andrews, Stephen Kirk, Lindgren, Mark Sonnenblick, Daniel Rojas, and Ian Eisendrath


If you‚Äôre looking for some drama, Korean actors Ahn Hyo-seop and Byung Hun Lee are also part of the film!
KPop Demon Hunters will premiere on Netflix on June 20. Check out the trailer below.

title: Proposed Muslim development in Texas brings inquiries by DOJ and state officials
description: The project, known as EPIC City, has yet to break ground, but members of this Muslim community feel stereotyped.
full_text:
The Plano EPIC mosque is seen behind a row of homes in Plano. Many muslims like to live near their mosque to facilitate practicing their faith daily.
                
                    
                    Yfat Yossifor/KERA
                    
                
                hide caption
            


            toggle caption
    

    
        
        Yfat Yossifor/KERA
        
    

   
   DALLAS, Texas ‚Äî The Department of Justice is investigating a proposed Muslim housing development in North Texas known as EPIC City for potential religious discrimination.   Top state officials, including Republican Governor Greg Abbott, have also launched investigations even though the project's developers say they're years away from breaking ground.   The East Plano Islamic Center ‚Äì also known as EPIC ‚Äì is a large mosque in Plano, a suburb north of Dallas. The mosque is running out of room as newcomers flock to the growing North Texas region.   A member of EPIC who is a realtor proposed a solution when he saw some land for sale ‚Äì why not build another community to accommodate the growing Muslim population in North Texas?   
   Growing community   Several of EPIC's members live within walking distance from the mosque.   Black and white houses with manicured lawns in the adjoining neighborhood are adorned with Arabic lettering. There's a grocery store up the road from the mosque called EPIC Market that sells halal meat and a Yemeni coffee shop, Haraz Coffee, which serves pistachio lattes and saffron milk cakes.   Fawzia Bilal lives close to the mosque. She says it makes it easier for her to integrate prayer into her daily routine. Muslims pray facing in the direction of Mecca, their holy land, five times a day. And holy periods like Ramadan call for additional prayer.   "I'm able to do this without getting into traffic or thinking about jumping into a car, walking distance," Bilal said. "I mean, it's all about honestly convenience and then the consistency with which we're able to practice our faith."   
            
        
            
            
            
        


    
        
                Plano resident Fawzia Belal stands near a projection of the future development of Epic City.
                
                    
                    Yfat Yossifor/KERA
                    
                
                hide caption
            


            toggle caption
    

    
        
        Yfat Yossifor/KERA
        
    

   
   EPIC Islamic scholar Yasir Qadhi told NPR the mosque is running out of space for its 10,000 members.   "Why not build a purpose built community where all of the facilities, all of the amenities that people want are going to be within walking distance?" Qadhi said.   EPIC purchased the land for the project about a year ago. The 402-acre development would be in unincorporated Collin and Hunt counties, roughly 40 miles northeast of Dallas.   
   EPIC City would include a new mosque, more than 1,000 single and multi-family homes, a K-12 faith-based school, senior housing, an outreach center, commercial developments, sports facilities and a community college.   Qadhi said the first 450 plots for EPIC City sold out within days of its announcements on the mosque's website.   Future residents are purchasing shares to own a plot of land for future homes. In those purchases, there's a charge to help fund the construction of other buildings, like the mosque and school. Qadhi said that's how EPIC paid for the land, not external funding.   "The funds came from the very people that are going to be living in that area," he said.   The probes   Although EPIC City has yet to file for construction permits, Texas Governor Greg Abbott and State Attorney General Ken Paxton have already launched several investigations of the project.   The state's probes include claims the project could be discriminating against non-Muslims in violation of the Texas Fair Housing Act, along with alleging potential financial harm to potential investors and potential violations of Texas consumer protection laws.   Abbott said in a press release that the Texas Workforce Commission is investigating potential religious discrimination at EPIC City, which would violate the Texas Fair Housing Act. Abbott has accused the development, without providing any evidence, of creating a "no-go zone" that bans non-Muslims from entering.   Qadhi said the proposed EPIC City will not be exclusive to Muslim residents.   "It's an open community," Qadhi said. "Anybody can come in. We're welcoming people of all backgrounds and diversity and we're offering them facilities that we think would be very, very useful."   Abbott has also launched a criminal investigation of the project, although it's unclear what criminal statutes EPIC or the project developers may have violated.   Paxton has also not specified what consumer protection laws EPIC City may have violated, but he said in a press release the project has "raised a number of concerns."   
   Neither Abbott nor Paxton responded to NPR's requests for comment on the investigations.   Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) said the Department of Justice launched a federal probe in early May after he shared concerns about religious discrimination and Sharia law, which forms parts of Islamic traditions but is not legally enforceable in the United States.   "Religious discrimination, whether explicit or implicit, is unconstitutional under the First and Fourteenth Amendments," Cornyn wrote in his letter to the attorney general. "Religious freedom is a cornerstone of our nation's values, and I am concerned this community potentially undermines this vital protection."   Misconceptions about Sharia law and Islamophobia are at the center of many of the allegations being about EPIC City online and at a recent county government meeting.   Mustafaa Carroll, executive director of the Dallas-Fort Worth office for the Council of American Islamic Relations, said Sharia law is often misunderstood in the country.   "Your daughters are gonna wear burqas and your sons will be terrorists and they're gonna be killing people and people will be blowing folks up and all this kind of craziness," Carroll said. "That's definitely not Sharia."   Muslim scholars emphasize that Sharia law is deeply dependent on context. While conservative countries may enforce strict practices, Muslims in Western countries often do not.    According to EPIC, Sharia encompasses aspects of Islamic traditions like when to pray, how to dress and what to eat.   The governor's office criticized the Council of American Islamic Relations in a statement and accused the interfaith group of being linked to terrorism. The group denies those claims.   Abbott recently said in a post on X that Texas halted construction at EPIC City after he ordered the project developer last month to cease construction or face legal action because the mosque hadn't acquired the necessary permits or authorizations from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.   
   "The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality found that the group behind the proposed EPIC compound did not submit the required permits to begin construction," he said.   But Dan Cogdell, an attorney for the mosque, noted that no construction had begun at the site. He said Abbott's order and the state's investigations are premature.   "We haven't started construction," he said. "We haven't even filed for an application. It's like, good God, have a cup of coffee before you pop off."   Online misinformation   At a county government meeting early in March, Collin County officials heard concerns from residents about the potential practice of Sharia law in EPIC City.   "They will do the most Sharia compliance, including honor killings, stonings, marrying their young girls off to older men," said Krista Schild, a resident of Hunt County.   "Sharia has no freedom of religion, no freedom of speech, no freedom of thought, no freedom of artistic expression, and no equal rights for women," said Lee Breckenridge-Moore, a resident of Collin County.   Schild and Moore offered no proof to support their statements.¬†¬†   Moore referenced as evidence for her claims social media posts from Amy Mek, the founder and editor in chief of RAIR Foundation USA. The Southern Poverty Law Center has categorized RAIR as an anti-Muslim hate group.   One of Mek's posts that accused city and school district officials in Plano of colluding with EPIC to shape school policy received about 8,900 likes and 7,800 shares. A few days later, Paxton announced in a press release he was demanding documents from the Plano Independent School District outlining "potential connections" to EPIC.   Public vitriol   EPIC member Fawzia Bilal said the attacks on her mosque and faith are disheartening.   "If I'm going out alone, then there is this fear," Bilal said. "Am I going to hear something? Am I going to be targeted?"   
   Bilal said most people in Plano are accepting because the mosque has a strong presence and is known for its service and contributions to the community.   She hopes that message will come through.   "No matter how loud the voices of hatred are, the voice of hope and the voice of understanding and reasoning will eventually overpower these negative voices," she said.   In the meantime, Cogdell said EPIC will cooperate fully with all state and federal investigations. He also said he expects the political scrutiny to delay the project, leaving the Muslim community in North Texas with less room to grow.

title: I'm a New Yorker who went to Seattle for the first time. Here are 9 things that surprised me.
description: I was surprised by free bananas, cheap train travel, and hilly streets during my first trip to Seattle.
full_text:
Business Insider's travel reporter took her first trip to Seattle, and it was full of surprises.
                    
                      
                        Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                          
                  
                
          
    
    
    
            
              
              
              
                
                    2025-06-03T11:02:01Z
                  
                
              
              
                    
      
            
      
      
            
            
            
            
              
                  I visited Seattle for the first time in May after years of dreaming about it.
                  The city in the Pacific Northwest surprised me as a New Yorker.
                  I found a strange tourist attraction, a free banana stand, and a tech neighborhood full of nature.
              
            
            
            
            
            
            
              When my train arrived at Seattle's King Street Station on a sunny morning, I didn't expect the 1-mile walk to my downtown hotel to feel like a hike.I didn't think I'd find a chewing-gum-speckled wall in an alley later that afternoon. And when I felt my stomach growl while strolling the bustling streets the next day, the last thing I thought I'd see was a free snack cart.It was my first time in the Washington city, one I've wanted to visit since I was a kid. As I developed a taste for travel in college, I found myself taking road trips from California up the coast to Portland, Oregon, to see more of the Pacific Northwest.Still, Seattle was always too far north to include in my itinerary. In fact, I'd never had a chance to visit the state of Washington ‚Äî until recently.During a weeklong trip from my home in New York City to the West Coast of North America in May, I spent three days in Seattle. As a first-time visitor, I found the city to be full of surprises.
            
                
                
                
                  
                      
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I traveled to Seattle from Vancouver, and I was surprised to find that a train ticket was less than half the price of airfare.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  The author took an Amtrak train to Seattle.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          I've spent about 100 hours on Amtrak trains from the Northeast to the Southwest. In my experience, traveling by train in the US is typically more expensive than flying, though it depends on the route.So when I was booking my travel from Vancouver, British Columbia, to Seattle, I was shocked that a coach train ticket cost $50 compared with the $150 basic economy airfare on the same day.I certainly paid more in hours ‚Äî the train ride took four compared with the roughly one-hour flight. Still, I was excited to travel slowly and watch landscapes transform from one country to another.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I was also shocked at how much more comfortable it was to travel in economy compared with planes.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  The author's coach seat on the train.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          I'd traveled in first and business class on Amtrak trains before, but this was my first trip in coach since I was a kid. So I wasn't sure how it would compare to my countless experiences flying in basic economy.Since the ticket was less than half the price, I didn't expect the train seat to be so much cozier than the stiff, flimsy plane seats I'm used to. I even avoided the neck and back pain I usually get when flying.On the train, the seats felt wider with more legroom than on a typical economy flight.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          Walking a mile in Seattle feels more strenuous than it does in New York.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  A hilly street in Seattle.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          I stepped off the Amtrak train in Seattle at about noon. It was my first time stretching my legs since I'd boarded in Vancouver four hours earlier. With an indie-rock soundtrack in my earbuds and the sun shining above me, I was excited to lug my suitcase on foot to my hotel 1 mile away.But I quickly learned that a mile in Seattle doesn't feel like a mile in New York. The route was almost entirely uphill. When I stopped to catch my breath at an intersection, I noticed the street to my right climbed up even taller for as far as I could see.In my city, I walk a lot, but most of the roads are relatively flat. So I wasn't expecting to feel so exhausted after just one mile.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I was excited to visit the iconic Pike Place Market but surprised to learn it hasn't always been a car-free space.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  Pike Place Market.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          Situated next to the coast in Downtown Seattle, Pike Place Market is an iconic outdoor market with more than 200 stores and restaurants. I've been hearing about it for decades, so I spent my first afternoon in Seattle perusing the 9-acre shopping hub.On a sunny Thursday afternoon, the market was crowded with locals and tourists alike. I shuffled my way through what felt like a line to get a peek at the fresh seafood. When I needed a break from the mob, I found refuge inside a used bookstore.Every so often, a delivery truck would drive through, dividing the crowd into two tightly packed globs, but most cars weren't allowed to drive through Pike Place Market. This made sense to me, since each passing vehicle halted the pedestrian flow.But I was surprised to learn that the open-air market's cobblestone streets are normally open to all cars ‚Äî the city is testing a ban on cars aside from vendors, delivery drivers, and those with disabilities, The Seattle Times reported in April. The temporary ban began on April 23 and is set to continue until the end of summer.I was lucky enough to inadvertently schedule my trip during the ban. I couldn't imagine what it would be like if cars could freely move through the already crowded market.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I stumbled upon the popular tourist attraction, The Gum Wall, in Seattle.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  Seattle's Gum Wall.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          While wandering the narrow alleyways around Pike Place Market, I was slowed down by groups of tourists stopping to take selfies in front of a vibrant brick wall. The wall was spackled with an array of hues from peach to periwinkle.At first, I thought the specks of color were dried-up chunks of paint. But when I saw a pedestrian pull a gooey wad out of their mouth and stick it on the brick wall, I realized the wall was a gum canvas.I was shocked and a little grossed out upon my realization, but when I focused on how the wall actually looked rather than the germ-infested materials, I thought it was a playful work of art.Before you ask, no, I didn't add my own contribution to the Seattle gum wall.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I was surprised to find a three-story target downtown.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  A Target in downtown Seattle.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          I lost my charging port somewhere between Vancouver and Seattle, so I headed to a Target near my downtown hotel. Back home in NYC, the Targets I frequent are small and offer little more than a drugstore.So, I was shocked to learn that this location was a 96,000-square-foot, three-story establishment. While still smaller than Targets you'll find outside cities, The Seattle Times reported, the store had a wide variety of groceries, toiletries, and tech products.There were so many aisles of home goods that I thought I could decorate my entire apartment with its offerings.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I wasn't expecting the tech neighborhood to be so full of nature.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  A Google building behind a park in South Lake Union.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          Seattle has long been known as a tech hub where software engineers move in droves to work at big companies such as Amazon and Google.Locals told me I could find the booming scene in the South Lake Union neighborhood, home of the original Amazon headquarters. The company's presence in more than 30 office buildings led to the neighborhood's nickname, "Amazonia."Before visiting, I expected to find nothing but business-centric streets lined with glass skyscrapers in a tech-fueled neighborhood. So I was surprised by the large presence of nature in South Lake Union.The neighborhood borders Lake Union, where I explored a waterfront park filled with runners, bicyclists, picnickers, and geese. Locals said the park is dead on the weekends, but tech workers frequent it during the week. Nearby, the Google building had a whole forest of trees on the rooftop.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I'd never seen a free banana stand before.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  A pedestrian grabbing a banana from the complimentary stand.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          The pop of color caught my eye while strolling through "Amazonia." In an outdoor space between Amazon buildings in South Lake Union, the bright yellow trailer is hard to miss.I got a closer look and saw boxes full of bananas beneath the awning, and a sign that read, "Take one ‚Äî not just for Amazonians but for anyone in the community."I didn't expect to find a free snack stand in the middle of a city. Amazon previously told Business Insider that founder Jeff Bezos came up with the idea to provide a complimentary healthy snack with no wrapper. The stand first opened in 2015.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          I wasn't expecting to see an active volcano so close to a major city.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  Mount Rainier is seen from Seattle.
                                  
                                    
                                      Jeffrey K Collins/Getty Images
                                        
                                
                              
                          From a hotel's rooftop deck, a local pointed to a mountain in the distance and told me it was an active volcano.I could hardly see the volcano through the haze, but they told me Mount Rainier, which last erupted in 1894, was more visible on clear days.I was shocked to learn that this city, home to nearly 800,000 people, is so close to what could be a natural disaster. According to the Seattle Office of Emergency Management, the city is a safe distance away from a blast's flow, but water and power resources could be affected.
                              
                        
                      
                      
                      
                          My trip to Seattle was everything I hoped it would be and more.
                      
                            
                            
                                  
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            
                              
                              
                                
                                  The author enjoyed her trip to Seattle.
                                  
                                    
                                      Joey Hadden/Business Insider
                                        
                                
                              
                          Seattle's mix of natural and urban lifestyles reminded me of my previous trips to Pacific Northwestern cities, which comforted me.But I was surprised by Seattle's unique attributes, including Pike Place Market and the oddly alluring gum wall.And since it was so different from NYC, I definitely plan to return to Seattle to get another break from the Big Apple.

title: Hafid F. Benamar : ¬´Le disco, c‚Äôest le genre de musique qui rend heureux¬ª

full_text: Proche d‚ÄôEric Judor avec qui il a notamment √©crit la s√©rie Platane, Hafid F. Je regarde les charts cor√©ens chaque semaine et je s√©lectionne les sons que je kiffe.O√π pr√©f√©rez-vous √©couter de la musique ?Quand je marche ou quand je fais du sport car √ßa me permet de r√©fl√©chir et de trouver des id√©es pour mes sc√©narios.Est-ce que vous √©coutez de la musique en travaillant ?Etonnamment non, j‚Äôaime bien me concentrer, en revanche quand je s√®che sur des id√©es, petite pause avec de la K-pop.La chanson que vous avez honte d‚Äô√©couter avec plaisir ?J‚Äôai un peu honte mais j‚Äôadore Gfriend, un groupe f√©minin de K-pop qui s‚Äôest s√©par√© depuis. C‚Äôest tr√®s fleur bleue mais j‚Äòadore !Le disque que tout le monde aime et que vous d√©testez ?Un album de Sade que mes cousins √©coutaient en boucle √† l‚Äô√©poque et que je d√©testais de fou !Le disque qu‚Äôil vous faudra pour survivre sur une √Æle d√©serte ?Ce n‚Äôest pas un album mais un morceau : Last Dance de Donna Summer. Le disco, c‚Äôest le genre de musique qui rend heureux quand on l‚Äô√©coute.Y a-t-il un label ou une maison de disques √† laquelle vous √™tes particuli√®rement attach√© et pourquoi ?La Motown, c‚Äôest tout ma jeunesse ! Pour moi, c‚Äôest le haut de gamme. Tu passes de Marvin Gaye √† Diana Ross ou The Temptations, jusqu‚Äô√† Michael Jackson !Quelle pochette de disque avez-vous envie d‚Äôencadrer chez vous comme une ≈ìuvre d‚Äôart ?Il y a en a plein comme Uprising de Bob Marley ou Thriller de Michael Jackson, mais celui qui nous a marqu√© √† l‚Äô√©poque avec mes potes, c‚Äô√©tait le verso de la pochette de l‚Äôalbum Power d‚ÄôIce-T, mais il n‚Äôy a pas que nous puisque Kendrick Lamar y a fait aussi r√©f√©rence.Un disque que vous aimeriez entendre √† vos fun√©railles ?Dur de penser √† √ßa mais je dirais Last Dance de Donna Summer.Savez-vous ce que c‚Äôest que le drone metal ?Pas du tout, attend je vais regarder‚Ä¶ Waouh ! C‚Äôest flippant comme truc ! Je n‚Äôarrive pas √† savoir quel est le but.Votre plus beau souvenir de concert ?Je dirais Al Green √† Paris en 2010. Je crois que c‚Äôest Ramzy qui m‚Äôavait invit√©, c‚Äô√©tait magique tous les sons √©tait bons !Allez-vous en club pour danser, draguer, √©couter de la musique sur un bon sound system ou n‚Äôallez-vous jamais en club ?Avant oui, on ne va pas se mentir, c‚Äô√©tait pour p√©cho ! Maintenant je vais moins en club‚Ä¶ je suis mari√©.Quel est le groupe que vous d√©testez voir sur sc√®ne, mais dont vous adorez les disques et inversement ?Houla, je passe cette question car je vais rarement en concert.Votre film musical pr√©f√©r√© ou votre musique de film pr√©f√©r√©e ?Il y en a plein mais je dirais Fame de 1980, la BO est folle !Quel est le disque que vous partagez avec la personne qui vous accompagne dans la vie ?J‚Äô√©coute de la K-pop, ma femme est moins fan mais mes enfants kiffent, donc dans la bagnole c‚Äôest K-pop time.Le morceau qui vous rend fou de rage ?Fou de rage ? Je l‚Äôai m√™me mis dans un √©pisode de la s√©rie Week-end Family que j‚Äôai r√©alis√©, sur Disney +.Quels sont vos titres f√©tiches ?Donna Summer, Last Dance (1978). Wonder Girls, Nobody (2008). Larusso, On ne s‚Äôaimera plus jamais (1999).

title: K-pop has been banned in China for almost a decade. Until now, maybe.
description: K-pop, which has been unofficially banned in China for almost a decade, may be on the verge of being allowed back in.
full_text: HONG KONG ‚Äî The concert was set to be small but significant: the first by an all-Korean K-pop band in mainland China after an unofficial ban on such shows for almost a decade.That was exciting news for fans like Haerin Ouyang, a university student in the coastal Chinese city of Fuzhou, where the South Korean boy band Epex had been scheduled to perform on Saturday.But the show was canceled earlier this month, less than two weeks after it was announced, leaving Ouyang ‚Äúheartbroken.‚Äù‚ÄúThe venue is only a 10-minute ride from my school, and it would have been fun to go with friends,‚Äù she said.C9 Entertainment, which manages Epex, cited ‚Äúlocal circumstances‚Äù in announcing the cancellation on May 9, dashing hopes that China was opening its doors to K-pop shows for the first time since 2016.The ban, which China has never officially acknowledged, began after South Korea announced the deployment of an American anti-ballistic missile defense system that China said was aimed at constraining its power in the region.Before the ban, China ‚Äî the second-biggest music market in Asia after Japan ‚Äî was one of the fastest-growing markets for K-pop and other South Korean pop culture, whose rapid rise in global popularity is known as the Korean Wave, or hallyu.‚ÄúIn the K-content and K-pop markets as well, China‚Äôs consumer power is regarded as top-tier,‚Äù said Kang Soyoung, a professor at Seoul Digital University.The China ban is estimated to have cost the South Korean economy almost $16 billion since 2016, she said.But the Epex concert‚Äôs cancellation does not necessarily reflect the official position of the Chinese government, Kang cautioned, as China has been gradually reopening to South Korean culture after years of tension.While K-pop acts have been blocked, other South Korean bands have been allowed to play. In April, the South Korean hip-hop trio Homies became the first all-Korean act to perform in mainland China in eight years. A South Korea-based Korean American musician in a one-man indie rock band performed in the Chinese cities of Xi'an, Wuhan and Zhengzhou in late 2024 and early 2025.A large-scale K-pop joint concert is also scheduled to be held in September at a 40,000-seat stadium in the Chinese island province of Hainan. The Korea Entertainment Producers‚Äô Association, which announced the event in April, did not reply to an email asking whether that concert is still going ahead.Kang said she believed the hallyu ban would soon be lifted and the Hainan concert would ‚Äúproceed without issue.‚ÄùThere are also signs of growing business ties. Hybe, the South Korean entertainment company that manages the global K-pop sensation BTS, recently opened an office in Beijing, according to South Korean media. On Friday, China‚Äôs Tencent Music was set to become the second-largest shareholder in the other major K-pop label, SM Entertainment, after Hybe said in a regulatory filing that it would sell Tencent its entire stake.‚ÄúIt shows that there is a greater opportunity for collaboration between the two countries, especially in the entertainment industry,‚Äù said Ellen Kim, director of academic affairs at the Korea Economic Institute of America. ‚ÄúIt might be a starting point for industry-level cooperation that could open more doors between the two countries.‚ÄùThe diplomatic thaw extends beyond culture. In November, China said it would grant visa exemptions for South Korean visitors, and South Korea has said it will do the same for visitors from China.China‚Äôs growing friendliness toward South Korea might be partly motivated by the unstable situation on the international stage, Kim said. Both countries face increasingly hostile and unpredictable U.S. trade policies under President Donald Trump.In addition, China is struggling with weak domestic consumption that would be aided by K-pop‚Äôs high-spending fans.EPEX performs on the music program "Show Champion" in Goyang, South Korea, on April 17, 2024.MBCPLUS / ImaZins via Getty ImagesChina has also been strengthening its own entertainment industry and has more confidence in it, Kang said, pointing to the record-breaking success this year of the Chinese film ‚ÄúNe Zha 2,‚Äù the world‚Äôs highest-grossing animated film ever.‚ÄúIt now has robust resilience against the ‚Äòinvasion‚Äô of foreign content,‚Äù she said.China‚Äôs potential thaw toward South Korean entertainment comes as it further restricts the number of Hollywood films allowed to be screened in its theaters in response to Trump‚Äôs tariffs.China-South Korea ties could also get a boost from next week‚Äôs South Korean presidential election. The front-runner, Lee Jae-myung, is considered friendlier to China than his predecessor.‚ÄúIf he wins, it might be a matter of time that things will change, which will allow the Korean entertainers to come into the country and play their music,‚Äù Kim said.Eve QiaoEve Qiao¬†is an intern on¬†NBC News's¬†Asia Desk.Julia ZhongJulia Zhong¬†is an intern on¬†NBC News's¬†Asia Desk.Stella Kim contributed.

title: Blackpink‚Äôs Lisa Soars To A New Career Peak At Pop Radio
description: Lisa and Maroon 5‚Äôs ‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù jumps to No. 19 on the Pop Airplay chart, becoming Lisa‚Äôs highest-charting hit on that list and first top 20 at pop radio.
full_text:
Lisa and Maroon 5‚Äôs ‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù jumps to No. 19 on the Pop Airplay chart, becoming Lisa‚Äôs ... More highest-charting hit on that list and first top 20 at pop radio.   BANGKOK, THAILAND - FEBRUARY 14: Lalisa Manobal attends "The White Lotus" Season 3 Bangkok Premiere at ICONSIAM River Park on February 14, 2025 in Bangkok, Thailand. (Photo by Billy H.C. Kwok/Getty Images for HBO)Getty Images for HBO
In just a few weeks, ‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù has become not only a hit for Lisa, but one of her most successful U.S. radio releases to date. The tune, fronted by pop band Maroon 5 and featuring the Thai rapper and Blackpink member, continues to climb several of Billboard‚Äôs airplay rankings. After a short time on the charts, the single hits a new, never-before-seen peak for her.


‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù Becomes Lisa‚Äôs Biggest Radio Hit
‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù rises from No. 22 to No. 19 on the latest edition of the Pop Airplay chart. That roster ranks the most successful tunes on top 40 pop radio stations across the U.S., and it‚Äôs where Lisa now earns a brand new career-best.


Last week, ‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù sat in second place among Lisa‚Äôs five appearances on the Pop Airplay chart. It landed just one spot behind the No. 21 peak of ‚ÄúMoonlit Floor,‚Äù a position that track reached in February. Now, as it jumps three spots, the Maroon 5 collaboration allows Lisa to enter the top 20 for the first time.

Lisa Follows Blackpink Bandmates Jennie and Ros√©
‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù is now the third-highest-rising hit in Pop Airplay chart history by a solo female K-pop musician. It‚Äôs just one spot shy of matching the No. 18 peak of ‚ÄúOne of the Girls,‚Äù which credits fellow Blackpink singer Jennie, as well as both The Weeknd, and Lily-Rose Depp.

MORE FOR YOU

The all-time best showing by any female soloist from the K-pop scene on this ranking belongs to Ros√©. Her team-up with Bruno Mars, ‚ÄúApt.,‚Äù is, so far, the only cut to ever hit No. 1 that credits a K-pop musical act of any kind.

Just last week, ‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù ranked as the fourth-highest-rising win that fits this description, sitting between Lisa‚Äôs own ‚ÄúMoonlit Floor‚Äù and ‚ÄúToxic Till the End‚Äù by Ros√©, which was stationed at No. 23. That ranking has changed, and ‚ÄúPriceless‚Äù could very well continue its forward surge in the coming weeks, and perhaps even months.


Lisa and Maroon 5 Hit the Radio Songs Chart
Lisa and Maroon 5 are currently climbing all three of Billboard‚Äôs pop radio lists. The collaboration may break into the top 10 on the Adult Pop Airplay chart next week, as it now sits at a new high of No. 11. The track, which has spent just two frames on the Adult Contemporary list, is up to No. 28. At the same time, the song debuts at No. 45 on the all-genre Radio Songs roster, marking Lisa‚Äôs first career appearance on that ranking.

full_text:
