title: Jackie Chan Action Thriller ‚ÄòThe Shadow‚Äôs Edge‚Äô Sells To Multiple Territories
description: Hong Kong-based Golden Network Asia has sold Jackie Chan action thriller The Shadow‚Äôs Edge to a string of territories, including Plaion Pictures for Germany, NK Contents for South Korea and Klockworx for Japan.¬† Currently in post-production, the film has also‚Ä¶
full_text:
Hong Kong-based Golden Network Asia has sold Jackie Chan action thriller The Shadow‚Äôs Edge to a string of territories, including Plaion Pictures for Germany, NK Contents for South Korea and Klockworx for Japan.¬†




	Currently in post-production, the film has also gone to SPI International for Eastern Europe, ATV for Turkey, Great Movies for Latin America, Shanghai Pictures for Malaysia, Prima Cinema for Indonesia, Shaw Renters for Singapore, Eagle International for Taiwan, Abnormal Studios for Cambodia & Myanmar and Izagur Media for Mongolia.¬†




	Negotiations are also underway for CIS, Ukraine, Benelux and other territories.

	






	Directed by Larry Yang, one of China‚Äôs most acclaimed new generation filmmakers, the heist thriller was filmed on location in Macau. The film is produced by Victoria Hon and backed by China‚Äôs iQiyi Pictures, Tao Tickets, Hairun Pictures and Chen Xiang.








	Chan stars as a retired surveillance expert from the Macau Police who is drawn back into action to support a team of elite young detectives fighting a criminal syndicate.¬†




	Chan previously worked with Yang on 2023 action comedy Ride On. The Shadow‚Äôs Edge also stars Tony Leung Ka Fai, nearly two decades after he worked with Chan on The Myth, Zhang Zifeng (Sister), Ci Sha (Creation Of The Gods: Part 1 & 2) and Wen Junhui, a Chinese member of K-pop group Seventeen.




	Leung also stars in Juno Mak‚Äôs Sons Of The Neon Night, which is premiering here in Cannes Midnight Screenings.¬†

title: No, That Was Not Rosa Parks on K-Pop Star Lisa‚Äôs Met Gala Outfit
description: Amid wild online speculation, it was revealed that the portraits on the black-lace jacket and bodysuit were designed by painter Henry Taylor for Louis Vuitton.
full_text:
Lisa attended the 2025 Met Gala wearing a Louis Vuitton ensemble featuring portraits by artist Henry Taylor. (photo by Jamie McCarthy/Getty Images)
			
			

		
				

					


	

		
		
					K-pop icon Lisa of Blackpink became the subject of controversy during the Met Gala last night, May 5, after netizens incorrectly claimed that she wore an outfit displaying an image of Civil Rights activist Rosa Parks across the crotch. There were indeed dozens of faces embroidered across her translucent black-lace jacket and strapless bodysuit from Louis Vuitton (LV) ‚Äî but these likenesses were all created by contemporary artist Henry Taylor, and Rosa Parks was not among them.Though Lisa has yet to speak out on the matter after countless news reports and viral social media posts, Hyperallergic confirmed that the lacy ensemble bore the faces of people close to Taylor ‚Äî friends, family members, acquaintances ‚Äî as is also typical of the artists‚Äôs signature paintings, which foreground Black individuals in intimate and community settings. The bespectacled portrait on Lisa‚Äôs body suit that many mistook for Parks is actually of the artist‚Äôs neighbor.Installation view of Henry Taylor: B Side at the Whitney Museum of American Art (photo Hrag Vartanian/Hyperallergic)Taylor had collaborated with Met Gala Co-Chair Pharrell Williams in 2023 for the latter‚Äôs debut collection upon his appointment as LV‚Äôs creative director for menswear. The artist provided the fashion house with samples of his existing portraiture, which in turn converted them into micro-embroidered embellishments that appeared on some of Pharrell‚Äôs collection looks. Taylor also painted Pharrell‚Äôs portrait for the cover of Vogue‚Äôs May issue.Taylor also attended last night‚Äôs Met Gala, which was themed ‚ÄúTailored For You‚Äù to celebrate the Superfine: Tailoring Black Style exhibition. He was styled by Pharrell, and wore a white button-down featuring his own embroidered portraits.Henry Taylor at the Met Gala on May 5, 2025, wearing a shirt printed with his portraits (photo by Jamie McCarthy/Getty Images)Pharrell also styled Lisa for the gala, along with rising popstar Sabrina Carpenter, Grammy-winning breakout rapper Doechii, and actor Jeremy Allen White. Lisa‚Äôs custom look deployed the same portraits included in Pharrell‚Äôs debut collection, except they were presented as black outlines rather than colorful embroidery.This controversy comes months after alleged videos of Lisa and other members of Blackpink reciting the N-word while singing along to several songs during their training days were leaked and shared across social media, adding fuel to the recent fire. The group has not issued an official statement about the controversy.	

	

	
			
															
																						
					

											
							Rhea Nayyar (she/her) is a New York City-based staff reporter at Hyperallergic. She received a BFA from Carnegie Mellon University and has a passion for small-scale artworks, elevating minority perspectives,...															
								More by Rhea Nayyar

title: Here's the first K-pop group with North Korean defectors
description: 1VERSE is the first K-pop group in the world to feature North Korean defectors. The group is the latest in K-pop to market multiculturalism in a cutthroat industry.
full_text:
1VERSE is the first K-pop group in the world to feature North Korean defectors. The group is the latest in K-pop to market multiculturalism in a cutthroat industry.   

    MARY LOUISE KELLY, HOST:  1Verse is the first K-pop group in the world to feature North Korean defectors. Its other members have roots in Laos, Thailand, China, Japan and the U.S. They're the latest K-pop idols to market multiculturalism in this cutthroat industry. Haeryun Kang tells us more about this unusual group from Seoul.HAERYUN KANG: (Non-English language spoken).1VERSE: (Non-English language spoken).KANG: When I meet 1Verse at their agency in Gangnam, a ritzy district in Seoul, the first thing I ask is how they overcome language barriers.SEOK KIM: (Non-English language spoken).(LAUGHTER)KANG: Body language. That's vocalist Seok Kim, one of the North Korean members.HYUK YU: Hello. My name is Hyuk. I'm from North Korea. I'm the rapper of 1Verse.KANG: There's also the main dancer, Aito Murata from Japan, Nathan Kousol, a Lao Thai computer science major from Arkansas and last but not least...KENNY HAO: Hi, my name is Kenny Hao. I'm from California, and I'm the personality hire (laughter).KANG: This kind of diversity is no longer unusual in K-pop. Now, they all live together in a dorm in Seoul, chasing the K-pop dream.(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "ORDINARY PERSON")1VERSE: (Rapping) Look, I said I wonder who I'd be, 'cause heaven ain't for me.KANG: The five members, who go professionally by their first names, all listened to different music as kids. Kenny grew up with The Beatles. Aito loved Justin Bieber. Nathan listened to Lao and Thai music. And the North Koreans?KIM: (Speaking Korean).KANG: Seok, who defected in 2019, listened to K-pop, illegally downloaded on USBs. He's from Ryanggang province, bordering China, where foreign goods are smuggled in more easily. But Hyuk lived much further inland in Kyongsong, a poorer region.YU: (Speaking Korean).KANG: Starting when he was just 9 years old, Hyuk cut down trees and even stole to survive, he says. Music was a luxury. The little he heard was state-sanctioned, like this revolution song.(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)1VERSE: (Singing in non-English language).KANG: Hyuk was the first trainee to join 1Verse. It took executive producer Michelle Cho six years to find all the members. She tells me about conceiving of the group with her co-founder, Joe Lim.MICHELLE CHO: Joe was thinking about, hey, do you think it'll be cool to, like, do a K-pop group with some North Koreans? Why not? If there's talented enough people, there is no reason why we can't do it.KANG: Back then, Hyuk was working in restaurants and factories. When Michelle Cho met Hyuk, she said she heard talent in his voice. From there, her agency, Singing Beetle, held multiple auditions for the others. For each round, they received hundreds of applications from all over the world, despite being a small agency just starting out.(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)1VERSE: (Speaking Korean).KANG: 1Verse already has over half a million followers on TikTok, and their first single isn't even out yet. Online, they're very active, making silly reels, singing cover songs together, like "Fools" by Troye Sivan.(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "FOOLS")1VERSE: (Singing) Only fools fall for you.YU: (Speaking Korean).KANG: Before defecting, Hyuk had never heard of South Korea, let alone Troye Sivan. He was just 13 in 2013 when he left his hometown, just 200 miles from Seoul, across one of the most fortified borders in the world. Today, he is one of some 30,000 North Korean defectors in South Korea.(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "ORDINARY PERSON")1VERSE: (Rapping) How to be one, just like an ordinary person. But can you show me...KANG: This song, "Ordinary Person," was cowritten by Hyuk. He raps in English, true to K-pop's strategy to reach a global audience. This is the only song the group has gone public with, as a teaser. Like other K-pop groups, 1Verse is very secretive about its official debut music. They won't tell me anything - the title, the lyrics, the dates, even the genres. Nathan just cheekily says...NATHAN KOUSOL: We can't wait to share our music (laughter).KANG: We may know their multicultural backstories, but for now, the most important part of 1Verse - their sounds - is up to our imagination.For NPR News, I'm Haeryun Kang from Seoul.

title: Democracy Wins a Referendum in South Korea
description: The newly elected President defeated an increasingly authoritarian rival party. Can he bring the country back together?
full_text: Just before 11 P.M. this past December 3rd, the Korean legislator Lee Jae-myung issued a dire warning from a moving car. ‚ÄúMy fellow-Koreans, you must come out to the National Assembly,‚Äù he said, in a live stream from his phone. The video showed Lee in a dark suit and a royal-blue tie, the color of his Democratic Party. He looked weary and frightened. ‚ÄúOur democracy is collapsing,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPlease come together to protect it.‚ÄùThe nation‚Äôs President, Yoon Suk-yeol, who was a prosecutor before being groomed for leadership by the People Power Party, had spent the past few years turning the machinery of the state against political opponents, trade unions, and journalists who criticized him. Now he had declared martial law and sent troops to lock down the parliamentary complex. But Lee and his allies hoped that they could prevail: because of South Korea‚Äôs recent history of military dictatorships, its constitution allows the legislature to constrain orders of martial law. The night that Lee issued his call, thousands of citizens showed up at the National Assembly. They helped Democratic Party legislators, and even a few conservatives typically aligned with Yoon, make their way past the soldiers and break into the building to vote down the order. It was an uncommon instance of co√∂peration across party lines in extreme circumstances‚Äîand, I argued at the time, a model for fighting authoritarianism elsewhere.A great deal has happened since. From December through April, there were ecstatic daily protests, demanding that Yoon be ousted. These were followed by Yoon‚Äôs impeachment by the National Assembly, his criminal indictment, his formal removal by the Constitutional Court‚Äîand, this Tuesday, a snap election to replace him. In the 2022 Presidential election, Lee lost to Yoon by less than one per cent. This time, he won by more than eight points. He will be inaugurated on Wednesday, beginning a five-year term.Lee is sixty-one years old, a scrapper with a potent backstory. He grew up in poverty, in the eastern part of the country, and got a job instead of attending middle school; his left arm was later crushed in a factory accident, causing it to splay at the elbow. He went on to become a human-rights lawyer, a mayor, and the governor of Korea‚Äôs most populous province. He has pushed redistributive policies, including universal basic income, while sticking to the Democratic mainstream. He is pro-development and pro-welfare state, loyal to the United States but respectably independent. Last year, he survived an assassination attempt at a public appearance: a man in his sixties, posing as a supporter and wearing a paper crown that read ‚ÄúI am Lee Jae-myung,‚Äù plunged a knife into his neck. The attacker had written a screed saying that he intended to save Korea from ‚Äúleft-wing forces.‚ÄùLee has been involved in numerous controversies. In the early two-thousands, he was found to have misrepresented himself as a prosecutor to help a journalist investigate a mayor suspected of corruption; he was accused of having an extramarital affair; his son reportedly posted misogynistic comments online. He has faced multiple prosecutions, including one for lying about his relationship to a real-estate developer during an election debate, in 2021. (Korea strictly regulates election-related speech; that case was appealed and is on hold.) The episodes provoked criticism that was often tinged with classist disdain; conservatives described Lee as a ‚Äúpetty criminal‚Äù who swims in ‚Äúdirty waters.‚Äù But a liberal friend also surprised me by writing him off as ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù and ‚Äútoo messy‚Äù to run the country. Far-right and evangelical groups targeted him for his views, labelling him a ‚Äúpinko commie‚Äù and organizing campaigns to smear him online.In the recent election, Lee‚Äôs main rival was Kim Moon-soo, a former labor minister who served as Yoon‚Äôs proxy. Kim is not a dynamic presence, but he upheld the party line. In one of three debates, he called Lee the country‚Äôs ‚Äúmost corrupt government official.‚Äù He argued that Yoon had been driven to declare martial law because Lee and the rest of the Democratic Party had repeatedly blocked legislation in the National Assembly. The People Power Party downplayed the attempted self-coup as a silly misstep. ‚ÄúThere was quick action to lift the martial law, and it got lifted, didn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Kim said in the final debate.I travelled around Korea in the days leading up to the election. In Cheonan, one of Kim‚Äôs campaign trucks blared music, while a surrogate shouted slogans through a muffled P.A. system. In Namyangju, a city in the province where Lee was governor, banners read, ‚ÄúA vote in this election is a win for the people‚Äù and ‚ÄúCast your vote to stop the treason!‚Äù Early voters in Seoul took selfies outside a polling station; there were long lines and lots of buzz, mostly in Lee‚Äôs favor.Nearly eighty per cent of eligible voters turned out‚ÄîElection Day was a national holiday‚Äîbut at the polls I visited the mood was subdued. I kept thinking about two other recent elections. The first was the Korean snap election in 2017, to replace President Park Geun-hye. Its contours were nearly identical to this year‚Äôs: misconduct by a conservative President, months of mass protests, impeachment, removal, criminal prosecution, and the election of a liberal replacement‚ÄîMoon Jae-in, who, like Lee, had been a human-rights lawyer. The second was the U.S. election of 2020, which Joe Biden framed as a plebiscite on a dangerously venal leader, and which came just after that year‚Äôs Black Lives Matter demonstrations, the largest in American history. Both Moon and Biden campaigned on who they were not‚Äîpresenting themselves as antidotes or correctives‚Äîwhile promising not to forget the social movements that brought them to power. Both ended up struggling to hold their country together, let alone effect the changes that their activist supporters had hoped to see.What will come of the resistance to Yoon? The movement‚Äîlarge, diverse, and energetic‚Äîwas largely sustained by young women, who waved ‚ÄúImpeach Yoon‚Äù signs to the beat of K-pop and adapted flashing L.E.D. batons, concertgoers‚Äô accessories, to the purpose of ousting a would-be autocrat. Yoon had made women-bashing a core principle. As a candidate and as President, he had fixated on abolishing South Korea‚Äôs gender ministry, and implied that feminism was the cause of many social ills, such as overpriced housing, underemployment among young men, and a record-low fertility rate. He surrounded himself with military generals. In a different world, the Democratic Party would have chosen a woman‚Äîperhaps a member of the National Assembly, which is about one-fifth female‚Äîto run for President to succeed Yoon, pushing for an omnibus anti-discrimination law that has been a perennial goal of women and minority groups.Instead, Lee largely avoided questions of gender during the campaign, and made no particular appeal to the labor movement or to poor people, constituencies he had previously courted. Determined not to alienate all of Yoon‚Äôs supporters, he called himself a ‚Äúreal conservative‚Äù‚Äîas distinct from the radicals who would institute martial law. Yet, as polls showed him taking a comfortable lead, Lee began to sound more like his old self. ‚ÄúDo you know why they‚Äôre against Lee Jae-myung?‚Äù he said to a crowd in Cheongju last weekend, referring to himself in the third person. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs because Lee Jae-myung is from the periphery. He‚Äôs on the side of small and medium-sized businesses, not big corporations. He stands with the poor and working class.‚ÄùLee wants to go beyond correcting Yoon‚Äôs strongman Presidency. But his victory feels more like a reassertion of reality than a referendum on the values of either major party. It is a vote against Yoon and others who would embrace a return to the military dictatorships of the nineteen-seventies and eighties. ‚ÄúFinally, that day of martial law is over,‚Äù said a man who celebrated the results in front of the National Assembly, to the news site Pressian.In office, Lee must contend with an unenviable pile of problems. Though some seventeen million voters got behind him, there is no consensus; the nation is split‚Äîby gender, class, and geography‚Äîand recovering from a prolonged political trauma, including multiple Presidential impeachments and prosecutions. The other, historic split, from North Korea, continues to inspire an arms buildup and a lingering paranoia over Communism. South Korea‚Äôs unemployment rate is around three per cent, but higher for younger workers. About half of the population lives in greater Seoul, for lack of jobs in the provinces. Outside Lee‚Äôs campaign headquarters, I attended a rally meant to highlight the precarious conditions of temporary and subcontracted employees; a few days later, a subcontracted worker died in a lathe accident at a power plant that was known to be unsafe. The auto and semiconductor industries, which together supplied more than thirty per cent of Korea‚Äôs exports in 2024, have been stunned by Donald Trump‚Äôs whipsawing tariffs.Still, Lee has reason to feel optimistic. His win is the sign of a functioning democracy and a refutation of authoritarianism. Late last night, on a stage near the National Assembly, he raised his good arm and pumped a fist to the chants of the crowd. ‚ÄúThe people are the masters of this country,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe President‚Äôs job is to bring the people together.‚Äù¬†‚ô¶

title: Netflix Releases ‚ÄòKPop Demon Hunters‚Äô Trailer
description: Directed by Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans, the Sony Pictures Animation film debuts June 20 on streaming.
full_text:
Feature FilmStreaming      
      
By Amid Amidi | 05/22/2025 5:25 pm | 
      
    
    
    
     
    Netflix has released the trailer for the Sony Pictures Animation (SPA) feature KPOP Demon Hunters from directors Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans. The film debuts June 20 on streaming.
The logline: ‚ÄúWhen K-pop superstars Rumi, Mira, and Zoey aren‚Äôt selling out stadiums, they‚Äôre using their secret identities as demon hunters to protect their fans from ever-present supernatural danger. Together, they must face their biggest threat ‚Äî an irresistible rival boy band of demons in disguise.‚Äù

The music-heavy film draws heavily on K-pop culture and includes original songs written and produced by Teddy Park, 24, Danny Chung, Ido, Vince, Kush and Dominsuk of TheBlackLabel, and performed by Ejae, Rei Ami, Andrew Choi, Danny Chung, Kevin Woo, Samuil Lee, Neckwav, and Jeongyeon, Jihyo, and Chaeyoung of Twice, among others.
‚ÄúI have been a fan of these incredible artists and their work for many years,‚Äù director Maggie Kang said in a statement, ‚Äúso it‚Äôs a dream come true to have original songs written and produced for our film by legendary talent such as TheBlackLabel. I also couldn‚Äôt be more thrilled about our collaboration with Jeongyeon, Jihyo and Chaeyoung of Twice. It really legitimizes our film and songs in the K-pop world. It‚Äôs proof that we achieved what we set out to do, which is make a real K-Pop group.‚Äù
Co-director Chris Appelhans added, ‚ÄúWe have an amazing voice cast, and the range of their performances is what gives the film such an original tone. Byung Hun Lee and Ahn Hyo-seop bring authentic K-drama emotion, while Arden, May and Ji-young blend the charisma of legit K-pop stars with the vulnerability and comedy of real young women juggling a dual life like no other.‚Äù
KPOP is SPA‚Äôs first release since 2023‚Äôs Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse. The studio has previously sold numerous features to Netflix for streaming premieres, including The Mitchells vs. the Machines and Vivo. SPA is also partnering with Netflix for the upcoming release of Genndy Tartakovsky‚Äôs Fixed after WBD‚Äôs New Line Cinema got cold feet over a planned theatrical release.
     
    
  
  KEY DETAILS
Directors: Maggie Kang, Chris Appelhans
Producer: Michelle L.M. Wong
Screenplay by: Danya Jimenez, Hannah McMechan, Maggie Kang, Chris Appelhans
Story by: Maggie Kang
Executive music producer: Ian Eisendrath
Original score by: Marcelo Zarvos
Production by: Sony Pictures Animation
Cast: Arden Cho, Ahn Hyo-seop, May Hong, Ji-young Yoo, Yunjin Kim, Joel Kim Booster, Liza Koshy, with Daniel Dae Kim, Ken Jeong, Byung Hun Lee
Co-producers: Scott Berri, Jacky Priddle
Original songs written by: Danny Chung, IDO, Vince, KUSH, EJAE, Jenna Andrews, Stephen Kirk, Lindgren, Mark Sonnenblick, Daniel Rojas
Original songs produced by: Teddy Park, 24, IDO, DOMINSUK, Jenna Andrews, Stephen Kirk, Lindgren, Ian Eisendrath
Original songs performed by: Ejae, Audrey Nuna, Rei Ami, Andrew Choi, Danny Chung, Kevin Woo, Samuil Lee, Neckwav, Lea Salonga
Featuring an original song performed by: Jeongyeon, Jihyo, and Chaeyoung of Twice
  
    
  
  
            
      
            
        What Do You Think?

title: Samsung is tapping some serious K-pop star power to sell its skinny phone
description: Samsung tapped Felix Lee, one of K-pop's hottest faces of late, to promote its new phone.
full_text:
Samsung has brought Australian K-pop singer Felix Lee on board to promote its new smartphone.
                    
                      
                        Scott A Garfitt/Invision/AP, Chris Jung/NurPhoto via Getty Images
                          
                  
                
          
    
    
    
            
              
              
              
                
                    2025-05-13T07:24:50Z
                  
                
              
              
                    
      
            
      
      
            
            
            
            
              
                  Samsung is enlisting some star power to promote its new phone.
                  Its latest ambassador is Felix Lee, a runway staple and one of KPop's biggest names.
                  Samsung released the Galaxy S25 Edge on Monday, a 5.8 millimeters-thick phone priced at $1,099.
              
            
            
            
            
            
            
              Samsung is bringing out the big guns to promote the launch of its slimmest phone to date.The South Korean electronics company released the latest Galaxy S25 Edge on Monday ‚Äî a $1,099 phone that is 5.8 millimeters thick and weighs 163 grams.Samsung tapped Felix Lee, one of K-pop's biggest faces of the moment, to promote the phone.Lee, an Australian-born singer from the South Korean boy band Stray Kids, made a joint Instagram post with Samsung Korea on Tuesday. The cinematic video shows Lee dressed in a black suit, his trademark blond hair slicked back.Samsung's new phone is set to kick off a new era of skinny phones, with the iPhone 17 "Air" rumored to drop later this year. The Galaxy S25 Edge ‚Äî advertised with the slogan "Beyond Slim" ‚Äî is set to go on sale in the US on May 30. It has a 200-megapixel, wide-angle camera and is integrated with Samsung's AI suite, Galaxy AI.Lee's fan base was quick to express excitement about the partnership. Reactions to the post included the comment "Who's getting this phone bcuz of Felix?" ‚Äî which had been liked more than 1,500 times at press time. Samsung first teased the partnership last week with a post showing the silhouette of Lee's face. It asked people to guess who the person might be and promised Starbucks gift cards to 25 people who guessed correctly.The Samsung partnership comes in an exciting year for Lee, who walked the runway for Louis Vuitton's Fall-Winter 2025 show in Paris in March.Lee was named the house's ambassador in 2023 and has become a personal muse of LV's artistic director, Nicolas Ghesqui√®re.Lee said in interviews with Vogue that Ghesqui√®re personally invited him to walk the LV Fall-Winter 2024 show in Paris. Before the March show, the designer said it was a "big honor" to have Lee there.This is not the first time Samsung has tapped K-pop talent to promote its products. In 2020, the brand released a special BTS Galaxy phone in collaboration with the Grammy-nominated band, and has featured members of the group in its ads too. And in 2019, Samsung also released limited-edition black and pink products in collaboration with K-Pop girl group Blackpink.Representatives for Samsung and Lee did not respond to requests for comment from Business Insider.
            
            
            
            
            
            
            
              
            
    
    
    
    
      

    
      

    
      
      
        
    
    
    
          
          
          
          
            
                
                
                  Samsung

title: American Music Awards 2025: Complete Winners List (UPDATING LIVE)
description: The American Music Awards 2025 are underway, with Kendrick Lamar, Post Malone, Taylor Swift and more leading the charge with the most nominations. The event, produced by Dick Clark Productions and broadcast from Las Vegas, is hosted by Jennifer Lopez. Janet J‚Ä¶
full_text:
Billie Eilish, Beyonc√© and Eminem were just a few of the big winners during the American Music Awards 2025, produced by Dick Clark Productions and broadcast from Las Vegas.




	Eilish won in all seven categories where she was nominated, including Artist of the Year, Album of the Year (‚ÄúHit Me Hard and Soft‚Äù), Favorite Touring Artist, Favorite Female Pop Artist and Favorite Pop Album (‚ÄúHit Me Hard and Soft‚Äù). She also won with ‚ÄúBirds of a Feather‚Äù for Song of the Year and Favorite Pop Song.

	







	Beyonc√© picked up two awards, including Favorite Female Country Artist and Favorite Country Album for ‚ÄúCowboy Carter.‚Äù Post Malone secured his first win in the country category, winning Favorite Male Country Artist, while Eminem won his first AMAs in 15 years for Favorite Male Hip-Hop Artist and Favorite Hip-Hop Album (‚ÄúThe Death of Slim Shady (Coup De Gr√¢ce)‚Äù). Gracie Abrams was awarded New Artist of the Year, while Lady Gaga and Bruno Mars won Favorite Music Video and Collaboration of the Year for ‚ÄúDie With a Smile.‚Äù Gaga separately reigned in Favorite Dance/Electronic Artist, while Mars scored Favorite Male Pop Artist.








	Jennifer Lopez returned to host the AMAs for the first time in a decade, opening the evening with a dance medley of 23 of the biggest hits from the past year. Janet Jackson was on hand to accept the Icon Award, giving her first televised performance in seven years.




	Taking the stage in a white jacket and baggy jeans, she gave a rendition of her hit ‚ÄúSomeone to Call My Lover‚Äù (featuring a brief mashup with Mariah Carey‚Äôs ‚ÄúShake It Off‚Äù). After wrapping with ‚ÄúAll For You,‚Äù Jackson accepted the Icon Award, stating that fame was never the intended result of making music.

	





	‚ÄúNo disrespect in any way, but I don‚Äôt consider myself an icon. My family, myself, our dream wasn‚Äôt ever to be famous. We weren‚Äôt raised like that. We always had a special love for music, dancing and singing, and fame came with the result of hard work and dedication,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy story, my family‚Äôs story, it‚Äôs truly an American story. This would have only happened in America. The one thing that I hope for is that I‚Äôve been an inspiration to others and artists, to follow their dreams and succeed.‚Äù




	Rod Stewart was given the Lifetime Achievement Award by five of his children and closed the show with his classic ‚ÄúForever Young.‚Äù ‚ÄúI am absolutely flabbergasted, I didn‚Äôt know they were here, my children,‚Äù he said during his acceptance speech. ‚ÄúWhen I started singing in the early 60s, well before all of you lot were here, the reason I got into it was because I had this burning ambition to sing. That‚Äôs all I wanted to do. I didn‚Äôt want to be rich or famous, and so many years later, I‚Äôm here.‚Äù




	Blake Shelton handled the first performance of the night with his song ‚ÄúStay Country or Die Tryin‚Äô,‚Äù while Lainey Wilson kept the country streak going with a rendition of her new single ‚ÄúSomewhere Over Laredo.‚Äù Gwen Stefani gave a medley of her new single ‚ÄúSwallow My Tears,‚Äù accompanied by renditions of ‚ÄúThe Sweet Escape‚Äù and ‚ÄúHollaback Girl.‚Äù Benson Boone brought the backflips for ‚ÄúMystical Magical,‚Äù while Renee Rapp debuted her new single ‚ÄúLeave Me Alone.‚Äù Gloria Estefan gave a medley of ‚ÄúRhythm is Gonna Get You,‚Äù ‚ÄúLa Vecina (No S√© Na‚Äô)‚Äù and ‚ÄúConga.‚Äù Alex Warren sang ‚ÄúOrdinary,‚Äù followed by Becky G teaming up with Manuel Turizo for the first performance of their duet ‚ÄúQue Haces.‚Äù




	Check out the full list of American Music Awards 2025 winners below:




	ARTIST OF THE YEARAriana GrandeBillie Eilish (WINNER)Chappell RoanKendrick LamarMorgan WallenPost MaloneSabrina CarpenterSZATaylor SwiftZach Bryan




	NEW ARTIST OF THE YEARBenson BooneChappell RoanGracie Abrams (WINNER)ShaboozeyTeddy SwimsTommy Richman




	ALBUM OF THE YEAR Beyonc√© ‚ÄúCowboy Carter‚ÄùBillie Eilish ‚ÄúHit Me Hard and Soft‚Äù (WINNER)Chappell Roan ‚ÄúThe Rise and Fall of a Midwest Princess‚ÄùCharli xcx ‚ÄúBRAT‚ÄùGracie Abrams ‚ÄúThe Secret of Us‚ÄùFuture & Metro Boomin ‚ÄúWe Don‚Äôt Trust You‚ÄùKendrick Lamar ‚ÄúGNX‚ÄùPost Malone ‚ÄúF-1 Trillion‚ÄùSabrina Carpenter ‚ÄúShort n‚Äô Sweet‚ÄùTaylor Swift ‚ÄúThe Tortured Poets Department‚Äù

	





	SONG OF THE YEAR Benson Boone ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚ÄùBillie Eilish ‚ÄúBirds of a Feather‚Äù (WINNER)Chappell Roan ‚ÄúGood Luck, Babe!‚ÄùHozier ‚ÄúToo Sweet‚ÄùKendrick Lamar ‚ÄúNot Like Us‚ÄùLady Gaga & Bruno Mars ‚ÄúDie With A Smile‚ÄùPost Malone Featuring Morgan Wallen ‚ÄúI Had Some Help‚ÄùSabrina Carpenter ‚ÄúEspresso‚ÄùShaboozey ‚ÄúA Bar Song (Tipsy)‚ÄùTeddy Swims ‚ÄúLose Control‚Äù

title: Ros√©: ‚ÄòWhat does freedom look like to me? Being anonymous‚Äô
description: Taking K-pop to the places other performers can only dream of, Ros√© returns to the BLACKPINK mothership this summer fresh from a record-breaking solo run. But, says your number-one girl, she still has dreams of melting back into the crowd
full_text:
Ros√© ‚Äì The Summer 2025 Issue9 Images

Most pop stars start out as pop fans. Then, if they are determined, agile, pretty and lucky enough, they‚Äôll get to become something like the stars they spent years studying and idolising. Ros√©, one of the biggest pop stars in the world, never got to be a superfan. ‚ÄúSee, that‚Äôs a big thing I don‚Äôt think I really got to experience,‚Äù she says. 
The singer, born Roseanne Park to Korean immigrant parents in New Zealand, was raised in Melbourne, Australia, and never had any posters of pop stars on her bedroom walls. She never spammed an idol‚Äôs Weverse, never wrote homoerotic fanfic, or queued for hours outside a concert venue. She really only started to learn about music and music culture at 16, right before she was whisked away to a training boot camp in South Korea, undertaking a regime that resembled the assembly-line approaches of 1960s Motown and Brill Building-era pop in the US. Her friends and older sister had only just introduced her to K-pop before she left. ‚ÄúThen I flew to Korea and practised in a basement for four years.‚Äù She emerged from it a pop star.



Speaking during a break from a fitting in Seoul, Korea, Ros√© displays all the behaviour you‚Äôd come to expect from her maeryeok (distinctive appeal). She smiles warmly, listens intently and forms little love hearts with her hands. She is one of the most instantly likable people I have ever spoken to. She‚Äôs wearing a relaxed white tee and dark navy hoodie, her hair falling into two braids with just the right amount of mess and tousle. She makes an effort to slouch against the nothing-coloured couch. Every girl in the world would think they‚Äôd die happy if they looked like this.
She coughs throughout our call, and even those are immaculate: three-beat hack-hack-hacks into her hoodie sleeve, dab-style, rounded off with a perfectly polite: ‚ÄúI apologise, I hope this isn‚Äôt annoying.‚Äù She‚Äôs in that last stage of a mild virus, following a week with her family (and Hank the dog), as well as a couple of surprise appearances with Coldplay at Goyang Stadium, the 40,000-capacity venue where she‚Äôll perform with BLACKPINK in a couple of months for the opening night of their world tour. She‚Äôs hardly said a word this past week; she‚Äôs been on vocal rest. In-between silent games of Scrabble with her team, Ros√© started learning sign language for the first time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really fun,‚Äù she tells me.
Her performances with Coldplay, a band who nowadays function like a nu-age, globalising engine of love and harmony, reenergised and inspired Ros√© for the tour ahead. Between glam and stage appearances, she watched the show from the wings, seeing how fans reacted to each confetti blast and lighting change. ‚ÄúIt gave me a whole new perspective on how it could feel to be a part of a crowd,‚Äù she says, an experience Ros√© still feels bereft of.

Each of us [in BLACKPINK] has gone out and been inspired and learned so much about ourselves, and now we‚Äôre coming back to each other with good energy

BLACKPINK, the biggest girl group in the world, is the most consistent ensemble she‚Äôs ever been a part of. Their world tour will follow a year in which each of the four members released their own solo works, and tried to figure out who they were without the collective identity of the band. Each of them, but especially Ros√©, used the opportunity to become more earnest in her presentation, trading BLACKPINK‚Äôs pyrotechnics and ruthless self-sufficiency for candlelit familiarity. The transition back to BLACKPINK, she says, was easier than anticipated.
After having her neck out as a solo artist and spending the past year promoting her album in the US, she‚Äôs now slipping back into muscle memory. ‚ÄúEach of us has gone out and been inspired and learned so much about ourselves, and now we‚Äôre coming back to each other with good energy,‚Äù she says. While she‚Äôs hung out with Jisoo, Jennie and Lisa throughout the year, it‚Äôs been several months since she‚Äôs seen the BLACKPINK behind-the-scenes staff, many of whom have been with the group since day one. Ros√© had tears in her eyes during today‚Äôs fitting. 
She opens her mouth a little and bites her tongue as I continue my line of BLACKPINK questions. She politely tolerates the first few, meeting them with vague responses ‚Äì it‚Äôs approaching May and they‚Äôve not yet begun rehearsal for the tour ‚Äì before politely interjecting. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she says graciously, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I should be the spokesperson as one quarter of the group.‚Äù A little disheartened, I scratch off some 25 BLACKPINK-related questions. Album? More tour dates? I‚Äôm afraid I can‚Äôt tell you.


All clothes SAINT LAURENT BY ANTHONY VACCARELLOPhotography CAMPBELL ADDY styling AERI YUNAll clothes and accessories SAINT LAURENT BY ANTHONY VACCARELLOPhotography CAMPBELL ADDY styling AERI YUN

Speaking for herself, Ros√© says that all she does is work. ‚ÄúLately, it‚Äôs been hard to ‚Äì what‚Äôs that word in English? ‚Äì detach myself and my life from my work.‚Äù She has decided to stop feeling apologetic about a lack of work-life balance. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always felt guilty for bringing work home but if you work until you sleep, I think that‚Äôs great. That means you love it. Even when I‚Äôm not working, my brain is.‚Äù She experiences no moment without purpose. Her life is a constant stream of potential material that she can later edit, condense, scrap, collate, and potentially turn into song.
She blurred the line between work and self permanently with last year‚Äôs full-length solo release Rosie, an album hinged on romantic weaknesses and dependencies, which showed she might be just as fixated on love as she is on her own career. On it, she traded BLACKPINK‚Äôs ideals of hyperachievement for emotional unravelling, insecurity, obsession and neediness. ‚ÄúTell me lies like ‚Äòwe‚Äôre OK‚Äô, promise ‚Äòtil your face turns purple,‚Äù she sang on ‚Äúnot the same‚Äù. The lyrics were gestural and easy to identify with, in a way that made it feel like collective processing alongside one of the planet‚Äôs biggest pop stars. Having mastered singing and dancing, Rosie was her opportunity to master vulnerability. ‚ÄúThat was the biggest gift I got to walk away with,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôve since learned to sit with myself and accept it and be comfortable with it. I‚Äôm really, really happy about that, and I think it‚Äôs a tool that I picked up on myself. I love it.‚Äù
Rosie performed with all the astronomical numbers we‚Äôve come to expect of a K-pop act, but more surprisingly, it ended up in both middle England and America, largely thanks to the ubiquitous and unavoidable ‚ÄúAPT‚Äù. During a time when every other pop star is promising to ‚Äúbring the fun back to pop‚Äù, ‚ÄúAPT‚Äù genuinely delivered the whole year 6 disco. With its optimally distinct hook ‚Äì ap-uh-tuh-puh-tuh ‚Äì and powerful jocularity, ‚ÄúAPT‚Äù became fodder for prime-time Radio 2 playlists and TK Maxx in-store music. The little sister of the family isn‚Äôt the only one familiar with Ros√© any more. Now, the grandma, mum, auntie and baby ‚Äì especially the baby ‚Äì are in on it too.

Lately, it‚Äôs been hard to ‚Äì what‚Äôs that word in English? ‚Äì detach myself and my life from my work

Rosie, which sanded down the usual excesses of K-pop, was a seamless integration into mainstream pop. Bang Si-hyuk, the chairman of Hybe, BTS‚Äôs agency, remarked at a US pop culture conference last year that ‚Äúfor K-pop to gain more fans in the global music market, it needs to be consumed more lightly as part of pop music, requiring expansion in both form and content‚Äù. Rosie made good on that promise, and ultimately propelled Ros√©‚Äôs success outside of Korea. Her record-breaking album became the most successful of all time for an artist of K-pop origin in America. It topped the Billboard charts, and is now well on its way to reaching six billion streams. Before the end of the year, Ros√© applied to terminate her copyright trust with Korea Music Copyright Association, conceivably to keep expanding her global reach.
With a little distance from the rollout of her solo debut, Ros√© reflects back on Rosie only according to her own internal metrics. ‚ÄúWhenever I do anything, I always ask, ‚ÄòHave I done everything that I wanted to? Is there anything else I could have done?‚Äô‚Äù With this one, says Ros√©, ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt have done the slightest bit more‚Äù. She put her ‚Äúheart, soul, and more‚Äù into it. That fierce work ethic most likely comes from her mother. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen her pour her heart out into absolutely everything she does. Growing up, it was amazing watching her work.‚Äù


All clothes and accessories SAINT LAURENT BY ANTHONY VACCARELLOPhotography CAMPBELL ADDY styling AERI YUNTop stylist‚Äôs own, wool skirt WHITE ABYSS, leather boots ACNE STUDIOSPhotography CAMPBELL ADDY styling AERI YUN

At home, her parents spoke almost exclusively in Korean. It wasn‚Äôt until she was three, when she started kindergarten in Auckland, New Zealand, that she began speaking English. She grasped the language instinctively, rolling and rounding out her Rs ‚Äì a rare feature of the Korean language, whose consonants are softened. Now, the two different languages form their own distinctive texture and gravity in her throat. The Korean softer and lighter; the English denser and reedier. They each inspire totally different characters. After living in the US for the past year, she says her voice has completely changed. ‚ÄúLately someone asked me, ‚ÄòHow do you speak in Korean?‚Äô And I started speaking and it was a whole different person with a whole different personality.‚Äù She‚Äôs thinking of learning another language, most likely more Japanese than she already speaks: ‚ÄúMaybe if I learned that even more I would have a whole different personality there as well.‚Äù
Beyond the linguistic differences, I‚Äôm curious to know how Ros√© squares typically American values of vulnerability with Korean values of inseong gyoyuk (humility and loyalty), but she gives cautiously diplomatic answers, politely dismissing the idea of cultural difference in favour of a universal narrative. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all human, and I think the same things trigger and heal emotions,‚Äù she says.
With her American publicist and member of her Korean team listening in, she generally sounds a little clipped. She is understandably nervous to speak on the record. ‚ÄúWords are forever,‚Äù she explains. I ask whether she has any Grammy aspirations, given the success of the album. ‚ÄúI mean, that would be‚Ä¶‚Äù she looks around her, pauses, then regathers herself. ‚ÄúOK, I want to answer this,‚Äù she says, holding her knees. She goes again, the talkshow voice switched on: ‚ÄúThat would be incredible. But I think if it means more to my community, it‚Äôd be special. That‚Äôs the first thing that I want, and whatever awards or celebration comes after it, that would feel extra-rewarding.‚Äù It‚Äôs a perfect pageant answer, but I suspect a sincere one all the same.

If you work until you sleep that‚Äôs great. That means you love it. Even when I‚Äôm not working, my brain is.

I ask a few more seemingly innocuous questions, but she can‚Äôt answer them. Like, does she have a favourite One Direction member? ‚ÄúI do,‚Äù she says, ‚ÄúBut I know this is going to make headlines so I want to be careful. It‚Äôll cause too much drama.‚Äù I think to myself ‚ÄòZayn?‚Äô, then leave it at that. I also ask whether she‚Äôll continue spending time in Korea or head out to the States, and she can‚Äôt really answer that either. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I don‚Äôt think I should be telling people my whereabouts,‚Äù she says, glumly. ‚ÄúSee, these are the things I have to think about, it‚Äôs wild.‚Äù
We talk about food for a moment instead; Ros√©‚Äôs comfort territory. While she used to eat almost exclusively Asian food, Korean mainly, lately she‚Äôs eaten anything she‚Äôs been given. She just had her first In-N-Out cheeseburger after watching Jennie‚Äôs set at Coachella. ‚ÄúI just swallowed that right up, it was amazing.‚Äù
Now that she‚Äôs a celebrity who could have almost anything she wanted ‚Äì a cheeseburger, say ‚Äì I wonder whether she ever misses the feeling of craving. ‚ÄúSee, it‚Äôs interesting because I might be able to get a burger when I need burgers. But I think it creates a lot of things I can‚Äôt have besides that.‚Äù Like what? ‚ÄúLike not having to be terrified of small things. Like not having to be the annoying person in the room full of my friends who is paranoid about something when I want to be very nonchalant and chill, but I have to be careful about everything. And even if I‚Äôm not doing anything wrong, I have to think, ‚ÄòWhat if this makes people think that I‚Äôm doing something wrong?‚Äô And not always having the fear of being misunderstood. Like freedom.‚Äù And what does freedom look like to you? She looks around ‚Äì ‚ÄúWhat does freedom look like to me?‚Äù ‚Äì and answers, ‚ÄúFreedom means being anonymous.‚Äù


Leather jacket and brass and resin earring SAINT LAURENT BY ANTHONY
VACCARELLOPhotography CAMPBELL ADDY styling AERI YUN

In the past, Ros√© went to such great lengths to recreate anonymity. She once went out on the streets disguised as an old woman, hoping to feel what it would be like to not be seen. Of course, she felt more paranoid than ever. The thought that people would see right through it, know instinctively that this was Ros√©, never left her. The paranoia of a spy on a world mission. ‚ÄúIt was really, really intense,‚Äù she says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever do that again.‚Äù
I ask if she‚Äôd ever consider acting as a way to slip out of herself for a moment and become someone else. ‚ÄúWow, yes, I think that would be incredible in that sense,‚Äù she says. The question makes her think of the time she was hired to speak at a corporate event in Europe. She got up on stage, said, ‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm Rosie,‚Äù delivered a few lines, then faced one of her biggest fears: getting off the stage, walking from one side of the hall to another; walking through a crowd. ‚ÄúI was so anxious because usually when I walk through a big crowd of people I have to understand that people are going to recognise me and look at me.‚Äù But when she had to walk through the crowd of European businesspeople, no one seemed to notice. It was heaven. ‚ÄúI was jumping up and down after,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúSo, yes, I would love to act, because I‚Äôll get to feel what it‚Äôs like to be anonymous.‚Äù
She scrunches her lips a little, looks to her side. For now, she‚Äôs still peering out from the wings, trying to guess how it feels to be anonymous; a fan among a crowd.
Hair LEE SEON-YEONG, make-up WON JUNGYO at BIT&BOOT, nails PARK EUNKYUNG, set design IBBY NJOYA at NEW SCHOOL REPRESENTS, prop stylist KIM SOJUNG, photographic assistants YANG HAYOUNG, KIM YOUJIN, KIM YOUNGWOO, hair assistant LEE SEUNGYEON, set design assistants SEO JIWOO, LEE EUNSU, florist LEE SOHYUN, lighting and digital operator SHIN YOUNGJAE, production KELLY SUH at A PRJECT, production coordinator INDIGO CHOI, production assistants KIM GITAE, LIM JAEWOO, post-production TOUCH DIGITAL, special thanks SAM ROSS and PHOEBE SHARDLOW at NEW SCHOOL REPRESENTS

title: Singaporean actor Ayden Sng takes part in reality show where he learns to run a cafe in China
description: Titled U Sweet, or¬†Wei Xiao Yi Hao Dian, the show is set to run on iQiyi.¬†Guests involved in the reality show include Chinese singer Philip Lau and former member of K-pop group Exo, Huang Zitao.
full_text:
Entertainment
  
    
                                              

                        
          
      Titled U Sweet, or¬†Wei Xiao Yi Hao Dian, the show is set to run on iQiyi.¬†Guests involved in the reality show include Chinese singer Philip Lau and former member of K-pop group Exo, Huang Zitao.¬†


    
  
  

          
        
  
    

                                  
          

            
          

  

      


                    
      
      Actor Ayden Sng runs cafe for China reality show. (Photo: The Baeden Club/Instagram and U Sweet/Weibo)

        27 May 2025 02:23PM
      


      




      
    
  
  
        



              Singaporean actor Ayden Sng is learning to run a cafe in China for a reality show titled U Sweet. The reality show first announced his appearance in their lineup on Chinese social media platform Weibo on May 23.¬†

U Sweet, or Wei Xiao Yi Hao Dian, tagged the Weibo accounts of the cast scheduled to appear in the show, including Sng, and said in Mandarin: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not me, the waiter is watching the surveillance cameras. Could it be you guys?‚Äù.
              
  
            
            

            
            



                    
      
      Actor Ayden Sng is among the cast members of the reality show U Sweet. (Photo: U Sweet/Weibo)
    
  
  
              Set to be released on drama site iQiyi, the show follows 35 young men who undergo one month of professional training to learn the ropes of running cafes, from product development to store operations. They are then divided into groups to go to different cities throughout the country to run a cafe.

Sng also introduced himself as one of the cast members in iQiyi‚Äôs teaser trailer for the show on YouTube.
              
              
  

            The Mediacorp actor, whose Chinese name is Sun Zheng, changed his Weibo username to ‚ÄúU Sweet Sun Zheng‚Äù and posted on his account about his involvement in the show on May 23. He said in Mandarin: ‚ÄúThis time at U Sweet, I will use my utmost concentration to develop baked goods and beverages, presenting perfect creations for everyone.‚Äù
      

              
  
            
            

            
            



                    
      
      Ayden Sng, whose Chinese name is Sun Zheng, changed his Weibo username to ‚ÄúU Sweet Sun Zheng‚Äù. (Photo: Ayden Sng/Weibo)
    
  
  
              
  

            The actor‚Äôs official fan club, The Baeden Club, also posted on Instagram pictures of Sng working at the cafe during the first three business trial days of the show.
      

              
              According to their post, Sng will undergo a five-day trial managing the cafe from May 15 to 19, before officially taking over operations in Harbin, China, on May 20 with three colleagues.

Guests involved in the show include Chinese singer Philip Lau, former member of K-pop group Exo Huang Zitao, Japanese singer Rikimaru and director-actor Tang Guoqiang.

Sng is best known for his roles in Mediacorp dramas All that Glitters, The Unbreakable Bond and Loving You.¬†

In January this year, he announced his first role in a China production in the drama Perfect Match, which is available on Netflix. He's also one of the hopefuls vying for the Most Popular Rising Stars award at the upcoming Star Awards.¬†
          



      
    Source: CNA/cg

title: Blackpink will be performing in Singapore in November
description: Hours after the release of an advertisement indicating that the K-pop group will be performing in Singapore in November, Live Nation Singapore confirmed that Blackpink will stage two shows at Singapore's National Stadium.
full_text:
Entertainment
  
    
                                              

                        
          Blackpink will be performing two shows at Singapore's National Stadium on Nov 29 and 30.
  
  

          
        
  
    

                                  
          

            
          

  

      


                    
      
      K-pop girl group Blackpink will be performing in Singapore this November. (Photo: Instagram/blackpinkofficial)

        27 May 2025 11:36AM
                        (Updated: 02 Jun 2025 11:11AM)
            


      




      
    
  
  
        



              Live Nation Singapore revealed on May 30 the seating plan and prices for Blackpink's upcoming concert in the country.

Tickets will cost between S$168 and S$428, excluding booking fees. With the exception of the VIP Blink Pit Package (S$398) and Standing Pen E ($168), the concert will be a seated event.

Unlike most K-pop concerts, both VIP packages for Blackpink's Deadline show in Singapore will not have a soundcheck or a send-off session. VIP ticketholders will instead receive access to a dedicated merchandise lane, a commemorative laminate and lanyard, as well as limited-edition gifts.
              
              Blackpink¬†‚Äì comprising members Lisa, Jennie, Jisoo and Rose ‚Äì last performed in Singapore in 2023 for their Born Pink world tour.

At Blackpink's previous concert, the highest tier of tickets was priced at S$398 ‚Äì an increase from the S$268 top-tier tickets during the group's In Your Area tour in 2019.

The ticket details update came a few days after¬†concert organiser Live Nation Singapore confirmed that Blackpink will be performing two shows at Singapore's National Stadium on Nov 29 and 30¬†‚Äì just hours after an advertisement by¬†digital payment company Visa¬†announcing the news.
              
  
            
            

            
            



                    
      
      Jennie, Rose and Jisoo wore Charles & Keith utilitarian boots at their Born Pink world tour leg in Singapore in May. (Photo: YG Entertainment)
    
  
  
              On May 27, Live Nation Singapore had revealed that the Singapore leg of Blackpink's upcoming Deadline tour will have three presale sessions.¬†

The first will be for Blink membership holders on the fan platform Weverse which will be held on Jun 10 from 11am to 11.59pm.

Visa cardholders should mark Jun 11 on their calendars as there will be two time slots to watch out for to get early tickets. The first is for Visa Infinite cardholders from 11am to 2pm. The next slot is for all Visa cardholders and will be held from 4pm to 11.59pm.

The final presale session will be for Changi Rewards members on Jun 12 from¬†11am to 11.59pm. Do note that to qualify for this presale,¬†Changi Rewards members will need to spend a minimum of S$200 in a single receipt at The Shilla Duty Free stores, Lotte Duty Free stores, participating retail and dining outlets at Changi Airport public areas (excluding Jewel) and iShopChangi between May 28 and Jun 9. The first 10,000 shoppers to do so will be entitled to one access code.

General sales will then commence on Jun 13.
              
              Other stops on Blackpink's Deadline tour include Kaohsiung, Bangkok, Jakarta, Manila and Hong Kong.

The tour will kick off at South Korea's Goyang Stadium on Jul 5.
          



      
    Source: CNA/hq

title: Why are there so many Aussies making it big in K-pop?
description: From New Zealand-born, Melbourne-raised Ros√© to Stray Kids and NewJeans having two Australian members each, how is it Australia has managed to produce so many homegrown K-pop stars?
full_text: With so many Australians doing big things in K-pop, a key question is why. How is it that Australia has produced so many homegrown K-pop stars?This is something Roald Maliangkay from the Australian National University has pondered.Roald Maliangkay is the Deputy Director of the Korea Institute at the Australian National University (ANU). (Supplied)And yes, he is named after the late decorated British children's author Roald Dahl.Professor Maliangkay specialises in popular culture in East Asia and has researched the South Korean entertainment industry throughout the 20th century up to the present day.He's come up with a few reasons why Australia is fertile ground for producing K-pop stars.Speaking the right language"I think one important reason is that a lot of the Korean Australians here speak Korean, maybe not well, but they are fairly recent migrants," Professor Maliangkay said."It's usually their parents who migrate to Australia and that means that their parents will speak Korean at home."I think that's one important reason so that makes it very likely for the trainees, which they are at first, to at least be familiar with the sounds so they can pick up Korean quite easily even if they didn't always speak Korean at home or outside in public."So, I think the language aspect is quite significant."Greater convergence of Asian AustraliansProfessor Maliangkay says demographics plays a part."I read a piece by Jayson Chun who wrote on the website of the International Institute for Asian Studies recently that the number of Australians who are Asian is about 17.4 per cent,"  Professor Maliangkay said."Of course, we are a very small country in terms of population but if you look at cities like Sydney and Melbourne then the concentration of Asians around you will be much greater which probably provides a bit of an impetus for young people to try and establish their own identity and be noticed."And I think that is another driver for young Australians with an Asian background to perhaps try their luck at becoming a K-pop artist."The way Australians communicate"Another factor is that communication amongst Australians tends to be rather positive," Professor Maliangkay said."People here communicate in a very positive manner."Australians are really good at representing themselves and in engaging in conversation so that also makes things easy for an agency."Australians are generally very polite, they're pleasant and they use a lot of words like fantastic, wonderful and great, which when you go to Britain that is not exactly the case."Are politics at play?Professor Maliangkay says it's unlikely there are political reasons at play, but it could be a tiny factor."I don't think it is very likely that it's a political decision not to go with a United States-born artist," he said."But I do think that it's a little easier for Chinese fans to fall in love with a non-US based idol than it is when you're dealing with someone born in Australia."It's a tiny factor and the fans ultimately will fall in love anyway, but I think it might make things just a little easier."The time difference"If you're a young person and you want to go to a workshop in Korea and try your luck at an audition, at the moment, the time difference between us and Seoul is one hour only," Professor Maliangkay said."So, that makes going back-and-forth even when you're in high school just a little easier."Again, that's a tiny reason just like the political one but the other reasons I'm more sure of, that is, the language aspect, the greater convergence of Asian Australians and then the communication and the representation of Australians in general."So, who has made it big and who is on their way?Blackpink's Ros√©Blackpink's Ros√© made history when her collaboration with Bruno Mars APT debuted at number one on the ARIA singles chart making her the first solo female K-pop star to top the ARIA chart."She was born in New Zealand but then she was raised in Melbourne, I think from the age of seven and then she trained herself singing in church choirs," says Professor Maliangkay."She just suddenly had the courage when she was quite young, I think she was 16, to pack her bags and go to YG entertainment where she went to train, and it worked out."In the beginning, she was an absolute nobody, of course, and risked a lot doing all this and spending money on this."In interviews, she's very modest about it because this was really quite a risk she took and then, of course, now she's just this global superstar."Hanni and Danielle from NewJeansNewJeans broke a Guinness World Record when they became the fastest K-pop act to reach a billion streams on Spotify, unseating BTS.They have two Australian members."Danielle was born outside a big city, in Newcastle, NSW," Professor Maliangkay said.Danielle from NewJeans was born in Newcastle, NSW. (Supplied: Courtesy of ADOR)"She has an Australian father and a Korean mother."And they moved to Korea in 2019 at around the age of 14."She was kind of scouted by HYBE."Hanni was born in Melbourne to Vietnamese parents.Hanni from NewJeans was born in Melbourne. (Supplied: Courtesy of ADOR)"[She] moved to Seoul around 2020 at the age of 16 so that would make her 21 right now."She also ended up with the same company, with HYBE."What's going on with HYBE?Fans of K-pop would be aware of some recent news surrounding the multinational entertainment company HYBE."HYBE has come under serious scrutiny,"  Professor Maliangkay said."Although the company has responded to the recent allegations of insider trading by a former executive saying it is fully cooperating with the authorities, it denies any wrongdoing by chairman Bang Si-hyuk."And yet, since December, Bang has been under police investigation on suspicion of profiting by as much as $450 million from misleading shareholders during the company's listing."HYBE has issued the following statement to ABC News on the matter."We cooperated with the authorities in response to their request for information concerning the conduct of a former employee."Regarding NewJeans, Professor Maliangkay says fans were distraught to learn of a stand-off between NewJeans and parent company HYBE."What is more, following the public fallout over management rights with former CEO Min Hee-jin of ADOR that began in April last year, NewJeans's activities have now been put on hold, with ADOR last Friday winning an injunction against the group members engaging in any unauthorised individual entertainment activities until the legal process has run its course," Professor Maliangkay said."The idols stand by Min and argue that HYBE's reorganisation of ADOR has turned it into something very different from the label they signed with."Conflicts between idols and their management over contracts are not uncommon. Groups like Fifty Fifty, Loona, and TVXQ have faced serious disputes, some of which have led to their disbandment."While the high stakes of investment and intense competition help explain the often inequitable nature of contracts, fans typically rally behind the idols, so the companies almost always stand to lose from public disputes."I suspect that quite a few fans will respond to the scandals either by not investing as much money in HYBE products, or embracing the idols of other agencies, or both."Despite the negative reports surrounding HYBE's management, however, fans' excitement for BTS's long-awaited return ‚Äî marked by SUGA's military discharge on June 21 ‚Äî will likely remain undiminished."HYBE subsidiary ADOR has issued the following statement."We express our sincere gratitude for the court's judicious decision to grant the preliminary injunction."With our status as NewJeans' exclusive agency now legally affirmed, we are fully committed to supporting the artists going forward."Felix and Bang Chan of Stray KidsStray Kids has two Australian members ‚Äî Felix (fifth from left) and Bang Chan (third from right, back row). (Supplied: Virgin Music Group)Felix was born and raised in Sydney and Bang Chan was born in Seoul and grew up in Sydney."Felix is the fashion icon, partly, of Stray Kids and he's doing really well in that sense in addition to of course being a very talented performer," Professor Maliangkay said."Bang Chan is also very much a composer."He has his own kind of composing agency as well."So, he's composed quite a lot of music for Stray Kids."He's also the leader of [the group]."If I had to pick the top K-pop groups at the moment, NewJeans and Stray Kids would be in that list."It's quite something to have both groups having two Australian members so it is significant and that's why I think it's very good to ask indeed why is it?"Because you do wonder why is it that there are so many Australians [in K-pop]."Lily from NMIXXNMIXX will be perform in Australia this month with Lily (third from left) returning home for the shows. (Supplied: Virgin Music Group)NMIXX's Lily is returning home this month to perform in Melbourne and Sydney."Lily was born in Marysville, Victoria to a Korean mother and an Australian father," Professor Maliangkay said."About 10 years ago, she left to work for JYP Entertainment."She signed a contract in 2015 and eventually then into 2022 she then debuted with NMIXX, which means seven years of training and preparation before you actually end up being a frontline act."It's a long time to just be training, it's a bit like doing a PhD."Jake from Enhypen"Jake was born in South Korea but then grew up in Brisbane," Professor Maliangkay said."He moved back to Seoul in 2019 and then trained under HYBE.Jake from Enhypen grew up in Brisbane. (Supplied: Courtesy of BELIFT LAB)"Roughly after one year he was made part of Enhypen and I think they're doing quite well."Of course, Brisbane also has a very large Asian community, so I suppose there's a little bit of an impetus for young Asian Australians to kind of stand out a little bit and do something different, be noticed, and then of course with all trainees the lure of fame, money, fashion, and perhaps cosmetic surgery, which is definitely one of the perks, because the agencies will help you arrange that."Mackiah from ampers&one and n.SSign's RobinOthers to watch out for are Robin from n.SSign, who has debuted, and who said on TikTok that he went to the same school as Felix from Stray Kids and cites the whole group as role models.AndMackiah from ampers&one who is from Western Sydney and debuted in 2023.

title: Tyla Releases Sultry New Song ‚ÄúBliss‚Äù: Stream
description: Tyla has released ‚ÄúBliss,‚Äù a new single that she first teased to fans at her weekend two Coachella performance in April.
full_text:
Amapiano star Tyla has released ‚ÄúBliss‚Äù a new single she first previewed during her second Coachella set. Listen to the steamy song below.
‚ÄúBliss‚Äù was produced by Nolan Lambroza, Dylan Wiggins, and NovaWav. Over some flirtatious lyrics, Tyla sings about a lover she never wants to part with: ‚ÄúYou take me to bliss/ Never felt a love like this.‚Äù
Get Tyla Tickets Here
Last month, the South African pop star made her debut debuted at Coachella 2025. She is next set to play two festival slots in June at Governors Ball in New York and Bonnaroo in Tennessee.
Tyla‚Äôs 2024 self-titled debut album brought hits like ‚ÄúWater‚Äù and ‚ÄúTruth or Dare,‚Äù with the former earning the inaugural Grammy for Best African Music Performance. Later that year, she released a deluxe edition of Tyla, which included the track ‚ÄúPush 2 Start.‚Äù More recently, she contributed to K-pop star LISA‚Äôs debut album Alter Ego with the track ‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm with You.‚Äù

title: Waterbomb Singapore 2025: 2NE1, Shinee's Taemin and Minho, Whylucas and more announced as performers
description: On Friday (May 16), organisers of this year's edition of Waterbomb Singapore revealed the next wave of acts performing at the two-day event at Sentosa's Siloso Beach.
full_text:
Entertainment
  
    
                                              

                        
          On Friday (May 16), organisers of this year's edition of Waterbomb Singapore revealed the next wave of acts performing at the two-day event at Sentosa's Siloso Beach.
  
  

          
        
  
    

                                  
          

            
          

  

      


                    
      
      K-pop girl group 2NE1 and Shinee members Minho and Taemin are amongst the recently-announced acts performing at Waterbomb Singapore 2025. (Photos: Instagram/chaelincl, shinee)

    
  
                      

    
	



        New: You can now listen to articles.
        
            

  

      

        
    

    
       This audio is generated by an AI tool.
    
    




      
    
          
        
        



                  
      





  
    
      
    
  
  


  
        16 May 2025 10:38AM
      


      




      
    
  
  
        



              Get ready to bring some Fire to Waterbomb Singapore 2025 as K-pop icon 2NE1 will be returning to the country less than a year after the group's sold-out shows. The foursome, comprising Park Bom, Sandara Park, CL and Minzy, will electrify Siloso Beach alongside recently-announced performers such as Minho and Taemin of Shinee, CLC members Sorn and Seungyeon, and¬†Chuang Asia Season 2 breakout star Whylucas.

Happening on Aug 30 and 31,¬†Waterbomb Singapore 2025 will also feature a special collaboration between two powerhouse dance crews: Team Bebe and Jam Republic.

Other newly-announced acts include¬†Korean-Canadian singer-songwriter Junny and Singaporean singer¬†Estelle Fly.
              
              General sales for¬†Waterbomb Singapore 2025 are now on¬†via Pelago, with prices starting at S$228.

Previously announced acts for this year's festival include K-pop girl group Exid, Got7 member Jay B and Hong Kong singer Anson Lo.

According to organisers of¬†Waterbomb Singapore 2025, more acts will be announced at a later date.
              
              
  

            In a statement, Guo Teyi, Singapore Tourism Board's director of leisure events, said: ‚ÄúWe are delighted to support Waterbomb Singapore 2025, as it returns for its second edition. The music festival‚Äôs successful debut last year demonstrates its potential to attract music enthusiasts both locally and from across the region, further enriching Singapore‚Äôs vibrant entertainment landscape and reinforcing our position as a premier destination for world-class events.‚Äù
      

          



      
    Source: CNA/hq

title: Billie Eilish Dominates American Music Awards With Success In All Nominated Categories ‚Äì See The Full Winners List
description: Billie Eilish led the winners for the 2025 American Music Awards, the largest fan-voted awards show, which returned with host and performer Jennifer Lopez in Sin City‚Äôs Fontainebleau luxury resort following a two-year hiatus. The nine-time Grammy and two-time‚Ä¶
full_text:
Billie Eilish led the winners for the 2025 American Music Awards, the largest fan-voted awards show, which returned with host and performer Jennifer Lopez in Sin City‚Äôs Fontainebleau luxury resort following a two-year hiatus. The nine-time Grammy and two-time Oscar winner was triumphant in all seven of her nominated categories.




	Despite leading nominations with a total of 10 nods and having a banner year, Kendrick Lamar won only a single category, Favorite Hip-Hop Song, with smash hit ‚ÄúNot Like Us.‚Äù




	New categories this year included Album of the Year and Song of the Year, both won by Eilish, as well as Social Song of the Year, which Doechii‚Äôs ‚ÄúAnxiety‚Äù claimed.

	








	Artists Beyonc√©, Bruno Mars, Lady Gaga, Eminem, Post Malone, SZA, The Weeknd and Twenty One Pilots all took home multiple trophies.




	Performers during the ceremony included Blake Shelton, Gloria Estefan, Gwen Stefani, Rene√© Rapp, Benson Boone, and Lainey Wilson, and Janet Jackson was the¬†recipient of the Icon Award¬†for her legacy in music. Rod Stewart, who received the Lifetime Achievement Award, closed out the evening with an energetic performance. (See who walked the red carpet in their finery here.)




	The CBS and Dick Clark Productions fete aired live coast-to-coast at 8 p.m. ET on CBS, Paramount+ and Harmony, Deadline‚Äôs parent company Penske Media‚Äôs proprietary live streaming platform.




	See the full list of winners below:

title: The Studio Behind 'Spider-Verse' Just Dropped A Trailer For The Upcoming 'K-Pop Demon Hunters' Film
description: K-Pop Demon Hunters is an upcoming Sony film directed by Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans. The film follows a demon-hunting K-pop girl group as they go up against an unlikely new enemy: soul-stealing demons disguised as a K-pop boy band. The animation for the ‚Ä¶
full_text:
About
K-Pop Demon Hunters is an upcoming Sony film directed by Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans. The film follows a demon-hunting K-pop girl group as they go up against an unlikely new enemy: soul-stealing demons disguised as a K-pop boy band. The animation for the film was created by Sony Pictures Imageworks, the same team behind Spiderman: Into the Spider-Verse, and the soundtrack includes a contribution from TWICE members Jeongyeon, Jihyo, and Chaeyoung on the track "Takedown." The trailer for the film received generally positive feedback in late May, with several internet users commending the animator's decision to depict characters with exaggerated, anime-inspired facial expressions. Other internet users expressed excitement over the film's primary antagonist being a K-pop boy band.
  Origin
K-Pop Demon Hunters is an animated musical film directed by Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans. According to Variety,[2] the film is animated by Sony Pictures Imageworks, the same team behind Spiderman: Into the Spider-Verse. The project was announced in March 2021, aiming to blend Korean folklore with K-pop culture.
The story follows Huntrix, a K-pop girl group that secretly battles demons, as they go up against their greatest foe yet; a K-pop boy band that steals the souls of their fans. The official trailer for the film was released on YouTube[1] on May 22, 2025, gathering over 700,000 views in a day.

The soundtrack includes a contribution from TWICE members Jeongyeon, Jihyo, and Chaeyoung on the track "Takedown." The film is set to premiere on Netflix on June 20th, 2025.
The Twitter / X[3] account @DiscussingFilm shared the trailer for the film on May 22nd, 2025, gathering over 8 million views and 75,000 likes in a day.

First trailer for ‚ÄòK-POP: DEMON HUNTERS‚Äô, a new film from Sony Pictures Animation.Releasing June 20 on Netflix. pic.twitter.com/aXU3sZQXbH
‚Äî DiscussingFilm (@DiscussingFilm) May 22, 2025
 
  Spread
Several internet users reacted to K-Pop Demon Hunters when it was first announced, with Tumblr[4] user @ankle-beez posting a now-deleted Sony Animations tweet about the film on March 8th, 2021, gathering over 1,000 notes in four years.

 
On March 30th, 2021, Artstation[5] user Nicole Arriaga posted fanart about K-Pop demon hunters, gathering over 2,000 views in four years.

 
Several internet users reacted to the official K-Pop Demon Hunters trailer when it first dropped in late May 2025, with X[6] user @broppis posted a screenshot announcing that three members of the band TWICE members contributed to the song "Takedown" in the trailer, gathering over 18,000 likes on a post that read, Never Kill Yourself.

 
Also on May 22nd, X[7] user @taejiurina quoted a trailer for the film K-Pop Demon Hunters, writing, "The exaggerated comical expresions, the low fps animation and the premise of a girlgroup fighting against evil (a boygroup) oh girl I'm SAT," and gathering over 33,000 likes in a day.

 
Also on May 22nd, X[8] user @zb1mp3 tweeted a picture of the Shrugging Nurse GIF alongside a caption that read, "once this comes out ik somehow the male characters will be the most popular and talked about."

 
On May 23rd, 2025, TikToker[9] @fufu_sijo posted a video zooming in on one of the K-pop boy band members, writing, "Guys, please hear me out," and gathering over 55,000 likes and 15,000 views in a day.
